content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												Ultra Street Fighter IV is not a game for everyone. It is a very hard game. A few hundred hours is the basic learning curve for essentially being a beginner. That being said even for people not planning on being competitive there's a lot of content just in the combo system. It's satisfying working towards just doing combos in themselves or eventually beating your first opponent online. That being said, this is where the true nature of this game comes out.USF4 Is a game of competition and self-discipline. This game will appeal to yourself if you always strive to improve. There will be an unlimited amount of times you will frustrated and convinced you hit a brick wall. This game is about gradual improvement, a constant cycle of finding new plateaus and satisfaction of overcoming them with practice, hard work and intellect. This is a personal game, you shoulder all the blame for losing in a competitive setting. If you are prone to rage-quitting then this game will quickly be deleted from your hard drive in anger.Pushing past this however, you see the evolution of play and how you express your personality and play style as well as who you are playing against. It's oddly intimate in that you can recognize someone solely based on their movements, actions and decisions. In every game it is you against another person, another individual wanting to get better and improve, wanting to learn from you as you learn from them. This is the addicting part of USF4 and Fighting games in general, your best friends are always your enemies and you push each other constantly. Nobody will ever truly be satisfied in being "good enough", and that's all the reason you'll ever need.Economically speaking it's the best ratio of purchase price to play time I've ever had and will probably ever have. Something like less than 2 cents per hour? Highly recommended. 10/10

content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												Genre: 2.5D Traditional Fighting GameSummary:SFIV is a footsies-based fighting game that emphasizes slow methodical play and meter management between rounds. Game features the inclusion of 'focus attacks', a universal move that grants a character one hit of armour and the potential to crumple the opponent; the nature of focus attacks allow characters to aggressive advance through attacks without infringing upon the effectiveness of projectile characters. Pros:- 39 characters, an additional 5 in Ultra Street Fighter 4.- The majority of match-ups are balanced (future update to provide further balance). - Decent netcode if neither player has much traffic.- Large established player base online and offline.- Great for players trying to get into fighting games. Will teach fundamentals through play and the abundant tutorials on the internet.Cons:- Single-player modes are lacking; arcade mode has terrible A.I. and the challenges aren't fun.- The game itself does not provide instruction to newer players.- No theatre mode for the animated clips from Arcade Mode.Neutral Points:- There will be a learning curve; it is a fighting game afterall. If you are a new player then you will be terrible for a while.- Input leniency allows newer players to perform special moves more easily but can become an annoyance at higher level play.- There is a comeback factor for newer players (Ultra) which becomes a tool at higher level play.- The plot is barebones, but hey, that's a norm for fighting games.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2015
Online has been patched. It was an issue on Steam's end, and now many problems have been fixed. Reviews before March 2015 lamenting online play might be outdated. Online isn’t perfect but it is definitely playable (and better than Netherrealm fighters at least).In my opinion this is one of the best fighting games on Steam. If you want a deep and competitive game or just want to jump into the genre, this is a great title to pick up, especially with EVO right around the corner. +Diverse roster of 44 playable characters+All classic SF2 world warriors (Guile, Sagat, Cammy, Akuma, etc.)+Good mix of SF Alpha and SFIII characters (No Alex or Q though)+Wide range of controller support+Very balanced. Every character is viable in the right hands.+Good soundtrack (Character themes aren't nearly as good as in SFIII: 3rd Strike though)+Useful training mode with attack data, input display, dummy recording, and even 2 player online training+Matches can get pretty hype+Runs well on PC (80 fps on an AMD 7770)+Solid netcode. Again, not perfect (unless you live in Japan) but most matches are smooth. +Lots of colors and costumes (everyone has at least 3-4 costumes and ~12 colors)+New unique Focus Attack system.+Extensive Trial mode gives a fun way to burn time if you want a challenge+Interesting Japanese ink brush art style with great 3D visuals (sort of prefer the old 2D sprites though). Fireballs look beautiful. +Online community is still active-V-Sync causes input lag-New Revenge Meter is built up by taking damage. At 50% you can do an Ultra combo. This feels like it rewards bad play and makes comebacks more common and less exciting. -Ubiquitous 1 frame link combos. These are much more punishable on a missed link due to the large reversal window, allowing players to mash out a dragon punch if you mistime your inputs-Typical cheap arcade fighting game A.I. with psychic reaction time. Final boss in arcade mode is cheap as hell-3 joke characters. Dan is funny, but Rufus was unnecessary, and El Fuerte should be removed entirely. -Character Select starts 1P at Juri and 2P at Hakan. Why not Ryu and Ken?-Did I mention El Fuerte? With USF4 what you get is a well polished, balanced, and deep fighter. What makes this game enjoyable to me is the high skill ceiling; every time I play I have the opportunity to improve my ability. Heck, even with the amount of hours I've put in I still kinda suck. Much of my playtime consists of playing in private lobbies with friends, which is always a blast. While Street Fighter may seem technically daunting, I definitely recommend it to those looking to get into the fighting game genre. A learning curve is definitely present, but the fundamentals you pick up from playing this will carry on to other fighters. This is also currently the most played fighting game in the tournament  scene, so those with a competitive drive should be satisfied. Whether you’re familiar with fighters or are a total newcomer, I recommend picking up Ultra Street Fighter IV on PC.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												Title: Super Street Fighter® IV Arcade Edition makes for a very intriguing title. It contains one of those fancy circle Rs which probably stand for something legal, so you don't have to worry about any legal issues when you fire it up. Title has you covered. This game is also rather super, as every single character without exception has a super move that can be activated when you have a full super meter. Each character also has Ultra combos, although the title will not reflect that until an upcoming change in 2014. Street Fighter IV is the defining Street Fighter of this generation, with over four street fighters to street fight as. Furthermore, this is the arcade edition. Arcades are known for many things, but I don't actually know what any of those are. I remember that I never wanted to play in them that much because I'd have to pay every time I wanted to try again, which would be extremely frequent. I'm terrible at this. Fortunately, you do not have to buy a respawn DLC, even though this is the Arcade Edition. Graphics: The game comes with graphics, many of which are even 3d. The camera does fancy spinning flying things when you do ultra combos, and while that may not be related to graphics, I feel that is a very huge selling point as there is no better way to emphasize just how hard you punched that little casual in his filthy jaw. There are also fancy effects you can put on the characters that make a subtle but noticeable difference I can't put my finger on because my monitor does not have a touch screen. At any rate, the answer to "Does Super Street Fighter® IV Arcade Edition have graphics?" would be a resounding "Yes!"Gameplay: As you might expect, Super Street Fighter® IV Arcade Edition does indeed have gameplay. As games go, I would call it very good gameplay. Combos are hard as verdammt to pull off and I have yet to actually do one in a real match, although I most definitely can show that training dummy (His name is Dan :) who is the boss of 10 hit combos by nailing him in the face with one. Inputs are pretty typical for fighter games, with the stick being used to make complicated motions really fast and my xbox controller probably isn't the best for this. If you like your circles being quartered forwards, then Super Street Fighter® IV Arcade Edition is for you. As mentioned previously, it does have more than four characters, and some would even go as far as to say maybe more than twenty. Some people would say more than forty, but I am not positive that they are very proficient at counting. Super Street Fighter® IV Arcade Edition also comes with the internet! The internet is very well beloved by many people, and in Super Street Fighter® IV Arcade Edition, the internet is as fast and fluid as ever. There is very little lag and I often feel like I am losing to a real person sitting right next to me! I once even tried to unplug their controller, but ended up getting my power cable instead because they weren't actually next to me. It just FELT like they were, because the entcode* is so good. Sound: The characters are voiced and say things like "I will win" or "You will lose". They also deliver classic lines like "Do you want to take this outside... ON THE STREET?!" punches and kicks also sound very much like punches and kicks, although they may arguably sound more like someone clubbing a baby seal. I am rather fond of the neat "whump" noise it makes when a hit connects.Characters can also be made to speak in Japanese instead, because dubs are ABSOLUTELY terrible in anything where they should be speaking in Japanese. Juri even laughs better in Japanese. Do her backwards grab and tell me I'm wrong. Title: 6/10 + 2 for legal coverage and impending updates to address present concerns (Is not marked as Ultra)Graphics: 8/10 + 1 for subtle touch screen effects (I would rank it a bit higher but Juri's neck looks weird. Tell me I'm wrong.)Gameplay: 8/9Sound: 5/10 + 6 for being able to listen in authentic Japanese with real and true-to-life subtitles.__________Overall: 9/9.75 I just averaged all the scores and the maximum points for each category and got this, I don't really know if it's accurate or not. *Haha, I meant to type netcode. "Don't be so hasty to point out typos, you stupid hobbit!"- a real ent playing Super Street Fighter® IV Arcade Edition

number of helpful: 64 of 81 people (79%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2013
												As an avid Street Fighter 4 player, I consider this game to be one of the best fighting games currently available.  Not only the character roster great, comprised of 30+ old and new fighters from the series to date, but so is the sophisticated combo system that is both easy to pick up yet difficult to master.  I wasn’t particularly a fan of SF4’s visual style and initially reluctant to try the game because of it, yet I’ve grown to appreciate the unique look and feel of each characters and stages that the developers faithfully recreated in this title.Like many similar games in the genre, SSF4 was initially released on console systems and then ported over to PC.  Luckily, the developer Capcom has done an amazing job, implementing number of customization options for PC, such as support for greater than 30fps and multiple resolutions including 1080p.  In addition, the game also supports many controllers out of the box including XBOX 360 controller and numerous fightsticks.  Outside of Games for Windows Live, game runs smoothly and the loading time is relatively short, so there isn’t much for me to complain about this quality port.Although brief single player portion of the game is quite good, the multiplayer is where this game truly shines.  Thanks to its improved netcode, finding multiplayer matches are quick and reliable.  Built-in match setups work consistently for the most part and despite it missing my favorite “championship mode” from a previous title, both ranked and endless mode keep the game interesting and fun.  I really like the replay / save feature as well, which helped me to capture and savor those favorite character match ups over the years.Super Street Fighter 4 definitely isn’t perfect and the game isn’t groundbreaking enough to likely persuade those of you who aren’t interested in fighting games.  If you hold even a little preference over the genre though, this is good as any place to start.  I wholeheartedly recommend this to both casual onlookers and fighting game fans.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												Ultra Steet Fighter IV is an update for the original Street Fighter IV which was released in 2008. Believe it or not, but this was my first experience with the Street Fighter franchise.  This game is a standalone product too, allowing you to just purchase this definitive edition. This update brings the total number of playable characters up to forty four - each of the characters also has a different version of them selves, meaning you have in effect eighty eighty different characters to play as. Street Fighter IV has one of the best combo systems I have played with, much better than the combo system in Mortal Kombat X to say the least. You can easily view the combos for your character on the pause menu, meaning you can learn them on the fly, The graphics are really quite nice too, it shows a cartoony style art much like the previous games, but with a more polished and finished look to it. All of the special moves and combos each have their own animation, as well as special effects, making this a really good looking game to look at whilst spectating. Each of the characters in Ultra Street Fighter have their own story line, so with 44 different characters, that is a lot of story to include! I was quite surprised at this amount given the very linear style of fighting games I have played in the past. Obviously some of the stories are more in depth than others, but each of them give you a good amount of content to see. I only managed to play this game on Easy mode, and even then, on some of the latter stages to the arcade mode, I was struggling. I would hate to see how devastatingly hard the normal and hard modes are, because I was having to retry plenty of times before being able to beat some stages. That being said, this is the sort of game that you will just get better at with practice, you won't be pulling off massive combos to start with (unless you are highly experienced with this genre) so it will take some time before getting right up to speed. I have completed four characters arcade mode, meaning I have another forty left to go, this has taken me just over two hours to do, so there is a heck of a lot of content on show here, and that is just the single player. Ultra Street Fighter also has a local and online multiplayer too which will really wrack up your hours with ease. I had one technical issue whilst playing, I for the life of me could not get the game to run in 1920 x 1080 AND full-screen. Not sure whether this is intentional of a bug with my game. It runs fine in that resolution and windows mode though. That being said, you probably won't notice it too much given the amount of time you actually get to look at anything else whilst playing. I can easily recommend Ultra Street Fighter IV, even though this was my first experience with the Street Fighter franchise, it really does a good job of introducing you to this style of game and giving you hours and hours of content too. To buy this game from scratch, the £22,99 price tag is easily justified with the quality and quantity of gameplay on offer. Tom's Score Card1) Stay away2) Only recommended when on sale3) Recommended4) Highly recommended5) This is a must playIf you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												The best fighting game in the last few years, it offers an addictive and engrossing experience. To master each character you will need to spend some time tinkering with each moveset, but once that character clicks in your mind (and fingers :D) it is a blast.If you decide to go online after practising with your favourite chars, you will find a good range of fighters available in ranked and/or endless lobbies. My favourite way of playing online is to activate in single player the 'fighter request' option, so you can practice with any character against the cpu, honing your skills while you 'receive' requests to fight some real people.Last but not least, I wholeheartedly recommend to anyone interested in the game to buy a fighting stick, it is essential to master the game. I know they are expensive, but nowadays there is a good range of sticks under 100€ that will allow you to feel sharper and precise controls compared to what you can do with a gamepad.If you are commited to spend some hours with the game, you will experience one of the best fighters ever.'The answer lies in the heart of battle'

content:
Posted: August 4, 2015
												So it's about a year until Street Fighter V comes out and people who haven't really took Street Fighter seriously are wondering if it's worth the purchase. The answer is yes.I've been a complete casual Street Fighter player for years. But gradually over the years I always saw the pros and wonder if I can compete at their same level. Quite honestly anything is possible.. Except in a fighting game you don't rely on what level you are, or what kind of stats and skills determine the outcome of your character. It all boils down to memorization, muscle memory, adaptation. Honestly, the entire point of Street Fighter is the interesting aspect of the mind games between 2 players. It has the ruggedness of not a multiplayer game but some odd form of chess/board game appeal. As I played dozens of hours of this game I seem to realize it really does have a chess-like learning curve to all of these characters. As long as you put forth the effort into learning patterns and the characters mechanics (strength/weakness) and overcome all the mistakes you've been making as a casual player, this is a very rewarding game. Anyways, All I'm saying is if you're looking for a worthwhile fighting game I suggest you pick this up strictly to learn the fundamentals until Street Fighter V comes out. Also, Online play is very habitable. Pick it up before V comes out I promise you.. You won't regret it.

number of helpful: 34 of 51 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												From an outsider's perspective, the differences between Street Fighter 4 and its three existing sequels must look marginal at best. The first game made its console debut back in 2009 and helped revitalise the fighting game genre. Super Street Fighter 4 surfaced a year later and added 10 new characters to the roster, but since then, the game-to-game differences have been tailored more towards the dedicated fans. Ultra Street Fighter 4 continues this tradition with five new characters, a trio of fundamental system changes and not so much as a story mode in sight.If you're not the kind of player who spends hours learning combos in the training room, discusses the finer points of character match-ups on a regular basis and stays up till the crack of dawn watching the Top 8 duke it out at the yearly Evolution Championship Series, then the Street Fighter 4 series' consistent lack of single-player content will be a tough pill to swallow. But for those who view Street Fighter as a competitive fighting game that only truly makes sense when two minds are trying to outsmart each other, then Ultra can be seen as both curtain call from Capcom and the most substantial sequel since Super.Of the new talent, Poison stands out as the easiest to get to grips with. Her lingering fireball and feet-first dragon punch mean she shares some shoto fundamentals with Ryu and Ken, but when you also consider her Rekka-like whip special and her command grab Ultra, it's clear that Poison isn't as orthodox as she initially seems. The larger than life Hugo, on the other hand, is about as heavy-handed as a grappler gets. His normal attacks have extremely limited combo potential, but if you can close the distance and land his wall-bouncing command grab, you can inflict severe damage.New girl Decapre can combo into her air throw from her launcher. She can also use the new EX Red Focus to land an Ultra off her Rapid Dagger special.If the fighting styles of a pink-haired cross-dresser and a gigantic wrestling simpleton don't sound like your thing, then the other new characters offer something a bit more technical. Elena returns from the Street Fighter 3 series with two far-reaching overhead attacks (must be blocked standing) and one frighteningly quick overhead special that can combo into respectable damage. In comparison, Rolento is more of a hit-and-run-style character with excellent mobility and lots of long-range pokes. He can quickly get out of trouble with his EX roll and his Pariot Sweeper Ultra will combo off anything stronger than a sneeze.The last character on the guest list stands out for two reasons. Firstly, she wasn't previously playable in Street Fighter X Tekken or any other fighting game; secondly, she's the first new charge character to grace Street Fighter in what seems like forever. Indeed, Decapre may look like just another Shadaloo Doll with similar moves to Cammy, but once you actually take her bladed gauntlets out for a spin, you'll realise that she's fundamentally different. Her variable dash can be cancelled into her slide, dive kick, launcher or even one of two baits, and while most characters tend to have one standout Ultra, Decapre benefits from two.Choosing which Ultra to incorporate into your game plan has been a core feature of Street Fighter 4 since Super, and now with the advent of the Ultra Combo Double system, you have the option to take both at the cost of raw damage output. Other additions to the core mechanics include the Delay Stand and Red Focus. The former prolongs the time it takes for your character to rise after a hard knockdown and is useful for escaping vortex pressure from the likes of Akuma, Cammy and Ibuki, while the latter lets you absorb any amount of hits in addition to giving just about every character a viable way to combo into their Ultra.Six new stages have made the journey from Street Fighter X Tekken. That should decrease the odds of getting Volcanic Rim on random.The fact that there's no way to elegantly highlight the impact of these changes without dipping into fighting game terminology just reinforces who Ultra is aimed at. The same is true of the extensive list of frame data tweaks that have been applied to the existing cast of 39. Evil Ryu has more health, Yun's EX lunge punch is (once again) advantageous on block and dragon punches are no longer safe after focus cancelling forwards. This might not mean a lot to casual players, but if you've invested the time with any one of these characters, then the chance to fight with a heavily revised set of rules is an offer that's hard to refuse.There's no way of knowing where Ultra will take the competitive scene or how much the changes will affect the overall balancing, but if you feel like going back to the series' roots to see how much damage Vanilla Sagat could achieve off a simple Tiger Uppercut FADC into Ultra (it's over 600), then the new Edition Select has you covered. This isn't the first time that Capcom has put all past versions of each character into one game, but its inclusion suggests that this will be the last chapter in the Street Fighter 4 saga. Plus, there's nothing like picking the definitive version of your character when you're trying to prove a point.Despite boasting a thriving community that streams regular tournaments and keeps the online competition flowing day and night, the Street Fighter 4 series has always been somewhat lacking when it comes to useful features. Ultra helps to remedy this with the option to record your matches while playing offline and change your button configuration while on the character select screen. Better yet, the Training mode has been expanded with a network simulation tool that lets you mimic input latency and a save state feature that makes practising your setups less time-consuming.Poison's Ultras basically boil down to a kick in the crotch or a whip-assisted assault on the buttocks. Tough choice…The only feature I couldn't find was a way to reduce Elena's health so I could test out her Healing Ultra, but that's a minor grievance. On the flipside, the new Online Training mode lets you practise against another player without health bar limitations. There's also a revised Team Battle mode that pits two teams of three against each other with a shared health bar that carries over between matches. It feels a bit gimmicky when weighed against the other new features, but at least Capcom has added something that isn't focused purely on the one-on-one experience.Taken as a package, Ultra is an easy recommendation for players who view Street Fighter as a sport. It offers highly refined gameplay married with a rich art style, and by acknowledging fan feedback in an effort to make a well-rounded game even more polished, Ultra feels like the work of a developer that's content to please its core audience rather than trying to grab everyone else's attention. That's rare, especially from a studio that was responsible for Resident Evil 6.The only thing that holds this sequel back is the sense that it was made on a fairly tight budget. It's the little things, like the meagre choice of "new" characters and the way that some of the new Ultra animations lack the dramatic flair of their predecessors. But with the development team's passion taking up most of the slack, £11.99 for the digital upgrade feels like a fair price. It's not the Street Fighter 5 that we've all been hankering for, but as the fifth (and reportedly final) version of Street Fighter 4, Ultra is an ultimate end in more ways than one.9 / 10

A simple game always goes more than his simple mechanics, that is the moment when you realize it, this is not a simple fighting game, this is not easy, this is so hard if you want to play the game in a high level skill. Because a high level skill is not about to do the largest combo, is about to know what your enemy is going to do. So basicaly if the game is simple, easy to do combos and the options that you can do or make, that actually mean that everyone could do what the mechanics let you to do because they are really simple. Then the important is not about to be good with your controller pad or arcade stick, the important is about to read your opponent: in what he is good, in what he is not, what he is blocking, what he does not block, what are the advantage of your character against the opponent's character, what are his common reactions, what are his common reversals or counter hits, when he is going to do a special move, when he is not going to a special move (DP). Do you understand? skills is the basic that everyone can do, this game is a mental game like every martial arts, just a electronic one because we are fat people that does not do anything else than going to work, make money and buy food to eat and living a pasive life sitting in our chair.btw, that's does not apply at all in online because you can't see your opponent, maybe you can predict some moves or understand some of his patterns. but the mental game is limited. actually online is about skills + your adaptation to the lag, offline is about the mental game.right now (03 of july 2015) does have a decent netcode. number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12
												Let's get started...Fight!Street Fighter IV returns with yet another version in Ultra Street Fighter IV, after the big successes of Super Street Fighter IV: Arcade Edition and Super Street Fighter IV updates. New characters and stages have been added in what is the definitive version of Street Fighter IV.Story: The story unfolds as you play through each character's Arcade Mode. We get to see the motivations as to why each character has decided to enter the Street Fighter tournament. Some are pretty interesting like Chun-Li's, where she teams up with Guile and Cammy to defeat S.I.N. and discover what happened to M.Bison. Others can be pretty silly. Dan's story revolves around entering the World Warrior tournament to spread the popularity of his fighting style, Saikyo. It is pretty humourous and ridiculous. Overall, the story is nothing too interesting.Graphics: Ultra Street Fighter IV still holds up even to this day. It's artstyle is unique and immediately recognisable, often looking like a painting brought to life. All character's attributes such as face, hair, arms and legs are heavily exaggerated often looking enormous and cartoonish. However, the character models are fairly detailed and the backgrounds have alot of personality and life behind them. Special moves are also good ot look at.Sound: Each character has a fantastic voice actor attached to them. They bring personality and charm to otherwise lifeless pixels on a screen. The dialogue they speak, special attack moves, groans and screams are all done very well and convincingly sell me that this is a memorable fighting game. Also, the soundtrack for this game is one of the best in the Street Fighter series. Each stage has it's own beat and more often than not it is iconic and will stay with you long after you have finished playing the game. It's the best it has been since Street Fighter II.Gameplay: Ultra Street Fighter IV is a pretty technical fighter. The speed of the game has been slowed down from Street Fighter III: 3rd Strike and is more about patience and watching your opponent carefully than simply button-mashing combos. It is alot of fun to have that back and forward duel with opponents, seeing who makes the first move and countering as neccessary. This is what Street Fighter is about. Not ridiculously long combos like Ultimate Marvel Vs Capcom 3 but reading your opponent and beating them through pokes, fakes and great strategy.Overall, Ultra Street Fighter IV is a fantastic fighting game. It rejuvenated my interest in fighting games and is one of the best Street Fighter games in recent memory. All gamers should try this game even if fighting games aren't their thing. 9/10.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
												I've clocked 1500 hours in Street Fighter 4's online multiplayer since August 2012. The game's main selling point is its online part, which allows you to compete against people from all around the world - but with the most recent upgrade a month ago in August 2014 called Ultra Street Fighter 4, this game's online component has been destroyed by the developers.Matches will randomly freeze for a second, unpredictably alternate between playing in slow-motion and regular speed within a couple of seconds, automated matchmaking will match players from different continents and introduce ever more lag, manual matchmaking doesn't communicate other player's pings in any reliable way, and finally, the game's rendering and network backend are dependent on one another in such a way that players with low framerates effectively lower the speed at which the match they're playing at the moment is running.Street Fighter is a very entertaining game, but it seems Capcom has completely written off the PC userbase.

number of helpful: 17 of 27 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												Street Fighter IV was a superlative experience even before today, but Ultra Street Fighter IV, with its well devised additions, has added the bacon to what was already a tasty burger – you don’t know that Street Fighter IV needs these mechanics until you’ve tasted it with them.With new characters, stages, modes, and careful tweaking of the entire roster, Ultra Street Fighter IV is without a doubt, the definitive version of Street Fighter IV. It provides a plethora of new content and a staggering amount of detail, all for its modest price. Its greatest feat, however, is that everything culminates into a package that casual fans will enjoy and fighting game enthusiasts will appreciate.Whether you consider it to be meaningfully different or pretty much the same old thing, the important question is whether or not it’s worth playing. That one’s easy to answer. The game is aging, but it’s still great. And if you’re already a Street Fighter fan, it’s hardly a question at all.It will make your blood boil at times, but even if you’ve never played a version of Street Fighter IV before, you owe it to yourself to give this definitive edition a go.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
												Yes, having a bunch of different clothes variants is amazing but doesn't shadow the fact Street Fighter is a pretty good game. I first picked this game up with huge anticipation. I've seen the tournaments, I've watched the Pure Pwnage episode on this, and I've played Street Fighter 2 The World Warrior back in 94' like it was Call of Duty to these kids today. To say at first, I was a little disappointed. However, with a bit of practice and exposure to unique combos and moves, I became immersed. Besides the regular arcade/world tour mode, the game also features a challenge option for you to try out and test every characters combos and special moves. This is extremely helpful to new players in learning how the game mechanics work. At first it seems impossible to do anything super or ultra combos, especially with all the joystick or d-pad movement. After hammering it out a few times in this mode, you get used to the movements and mechanics start making sense. Some moves require all three punch buttons to be pressed. I didn't know that it was supposed to be at the same time and tried hammering three quick punches to which no special move would occur. It dawned on me eventually to try pressing all three punch buttons which resulted in a successful special attempt. It can seem extremely difficult, challenging, and even apathetic, but stick with it and keep plugging away and eventually the control schemes all make sense. I felt the combos were a bit more fluent than what Mortal Kombat X's was. Just like in the old Street Fighter games, you can grab and throw your opponents. The basic controls are weak punch and weak kick, then medium punch and medium kick, then there is two variances of hard punch and hard kick. Within the game, the player is able to choose the costume, fight style and taunt of the fighters before entering the stage. There are two bonus stages that are also featured throughout arcade mode. Similar styles and patterns can be noticed between fighters where some feel balanced, some are wrestlers, and some are acrobatic. Story lines within the game don't tell a lot of story, but do give a bit of insight into the characters of the Street Fighter World. Each character has a short story segment at the beginning and then again at the end tell of their triumph.The graphics in this game are distinctive. It follows a 3D sort of pattern but it's definitely 2D. I really like the art style they chose and they way they chose to end fights. Upon delivering a final blow, players can see their final actions carried out in slow motion. Sounds are good and do not necessarily mimic the old noise were used to. None the less, some of the old sounds are noticeable while the new ones deliver the impact they are meant to deliver.Multi player is absolute overkill. I don't think there are many players like myself still stuck in the 90's trying to put two punch combos together. Match making does a decent job trying to pair you up with someone close to your talent but often feels like it misses big time. Either really get to know this game and spend time learning character move sets, or be stuck getting punched and kicked thirty times in a row followed by a special combo.Overall, it is a pretty good game. I'm not a huge fight fan, but I do like my street fighter.For future SF games, it would be nice to see them try to new things with the game and maybe even go for a 3D plane. I have no problems with the way things are now, but why not try to add a bit more? To buy the full version of the game it costs about $45... I think for $45 there should be a bit more into the game than small variations on fighting. And maybe for guys like myself have certain move sets for certain characters that fight in different ways? RATING : 7.4/10Gameplay B Story / Campaign B Visuals / User Interface B Sounds / Music B Replay-ability B- Overall  B-ScreenShots :  Ryu talking to himself, in a forest, by himself, prior to starting arcade/world tour mode Power/combo bars have been added at the bottom. I took this shot because the diversity of the levels and graphics are awesome Using the super combo to finish off an opponent  Finishing off the opponent with ultra combo

number of helpful: 27 of 47 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Street Fighter has had quite a long history behind it. First releasing in 1987 in the Arcades, the series became popular once the sequel, Street Fighter II released on 1991 and pretty much created the Fighting Game genre and the competitive scene for it. This now being the fourth iteration features a number of gameplay changes to the traditional Street Fighter formula as well as a slew of new and classic characters from past Street Fighter and Final Fight games. The story (Yes it has a story) is set chronologically after the events of Street Fighter II but just before Street Fighter 3rd Strike. A new World Tournament is arranged after Bison's defeat at the hands of Akuma (SF2) in order to draw out Ryu and use his hidden powers and complete a project. Besides the main premise, every character has their own intros and endings after defeating the final boss, known as Seth - a new character to the Street Fighter franchise.The gameplay's still top notch Street Fighter. The game's heavily based on pokes and footsies (throwing out safe moves and controlling distance to your opponent) rather than combography, like games like Marvel vs Capcom or Mortal Kombat. Almost every character plays differently, with the obvious exception of the Shoto characters like Ryu, Akuma and Ken.Street Fighter has a 6 button layout, divided by Light, Medium and Heavy and each by Punch and Kicks. (Eg - LP - Light Punch or HK - Heavy Kick). Unlike in games like Marvel vs Capcom, however, these inputs can't be linked by just dialing-a-combo, they have to be timed as the animation ends or you use an old trick found out that helps players link together these moves known as Priority Linking or Plinking. Every character also possess their own Special Moves, most of them CAN be linked from normals, however. Motions also vary per character as well as the requirements for executing these moves - for example, Ryu's Hadouken has the standard QCF motion plus a punch button (QCF stands for Quarter Circle Forward or in NUMPAD motions - 236), likewise, Ryu's Tatsumaki Senpuu Kyaku (Spinning Kick) has the motion reversed or QCB plus a kick instead of punch and Ryu's most complicated move, the Shoryuken has a "Z" like motion, (..or in Numpad reference: 623). Other characters, like Bison, have Charge moves. Charge moves are moves that require a direction to be held for a set amount of time, for example Bison's Scissor Kicks require you to hold back for a few seconds, then when you're ready to use the move, tilt forward and press any kick button, Bison will then execute the move. Kick motions are usually written in Numpad reference as: 4Hold 6+Button.NOTE: The Numpad References mentioned above require you to, of course, take a look at the numpad on your keyboard, an analog stick or a joystick go by that to divulge input information easier to Fighting Game Veterans and Newbies alike. In Numpad - 8 would be Up, 2 would be Down and 4/6 would be Front or Back depending on your positioning in the game.There's more stuff characters can do to further extend their offenses:*L,M,H Alterations to Special Moves: Almost every character, if not all of them - can slightly alter their special moves depending on the designated punch or kick used. For Example, using QCF+LP can result in a slow moving Hadouken, whereas using QCF+HP can result in a faster Hadouken. Some moves also come with different frame numbers, so maybe a Light version of a move is safe on block, but the heavy version of the same move is very punishable after you use it haphazardly.*EX Attacks: EX moves are that require meter to pull off (Read below) but are, essentially, buffed up Special Moves. EX moves are executed by holding two of the same button when inputting a special move. For example, Ryu's EX Hadouken would be QCF+LP+MP/HP.*Focus Attacks: Focus attacks are done by holding the Medium Kick button and Medium Punch button. Focus moves, if charged enough can soak up certain moves up as a counterattack and cause a Crumple State on your Foe (Crumple State means that your character is in an animation where they can't move, defend or attack). After a successful Focus Attack, if you input a dash, you can cancel out the residual animation and continue your offense or escape a failed Focus Attack before you get punished, some characters, however are unsafe even if they cancel out. A Focus Attack cancel into dash is widely known as "FADC" or Focus Attack Dash Cancel and these can be used to cancel out of some special moves. NOTE: Some moves WILL break through a Focus Attack, when they do, you'll hear a shattering sound, be mindful of this when haphazardly throwing out focus attacks.*Super Moves: Super Moves can be done when you have a Full Meter. Just like Ultras and Special Moves, they have their own input that varies per character. Using a Super will drain your entire Meter. *Ultras: Every character has 2 Designated Ultras, you can, however only choose one in the character select screen after choosing your fighter. In game, you get the meter to use your Ultra moves as you take damage. It is possible to use 2 Ultras in the same round.*Throws/Command Throws: Every character has a designated throw move. A throw can be done by pressing the light Punch and Kick buttons. Throws can be teched out of (Escaped) by pressing the Throw buttons just as you're being thrown. A throw can come out instantly and is often used for mix ups in an on going match. A Comand Throw, however, is only usable by certain characters, like Abel and Zangief. These have their own motions plus a button press, same as Special Moves, however, these throws are untechable and often deal high damage, but they aren't as easy to land as a regular throw.In game, you have three meters you need to keep track of as well!These being your health bar at the top, your Super Meter (Has 4 rectangles - each indicate an EX move that's now usable) and your Ultra bar by the side, which, when it lights up, means your character's Ultra is now useable.The game itself looks great visually with a lot nice visual effects that still look great to this day. The character models are a little bulky looking, but it's more or less to do with the game's own art style. The stages in the game look great as well, some are very vibrant and colorful and some have more animated backdrops in the stage to give it more authenticity to what you're seeing on screen.Soundwork is great aswell. Every stage has it's own theme to fit what you see on screen and helps further the authenticity of it, as well as some stages have their own added background noises. Each character also has their own theme songs and can be chosen to play them instead of Stage themes in the options menu as well as changing the character's Voices to English or Japanese. In game, everything also has it's own little chime that helps the player to identify them. When you gain a block of Super meter, it usually has a little 'puff' sound that helps you identify that you or your foe have a new block of meter to use. Hit noises are also fairly well done and help identify the more solid moves to give it more impact, likewise, the weaker moves, like light punches and kicks have their own sound that sounds less impactful but serve to help you identify that you hit your foe or viceversa.Overall, this is an amazing fighting game that no fighting game fan should miss. Not much to say other than it's Street Fighter. Great mechanics, a healthy selection of characters with high variation to them and of course, the game ALWAYS has something new for you to learn, even if you're seasoned veteran. Pros +Great Mechanics+Lots of Character Variation+Has an amazingly balanced roster+Amazing Visual Effects+Amazing Soundwork and soundcues help give the game authenticity and impactCons-Dodgy Online System

content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												Ultra Street Fighter IV, should probably be called the Ultimate Street Fighter IV since that is what it is. It has all the characters from the Street Fighter Franchise as well as some new faces and locations. 44 different characters to choose from with updated standout graphics that make the characters pop on screen. The game looks good, feels good, and for those of us who grew up with old school Street Fighter, it brings back a lot of memories. Ultra Street Fighter IV allows you to play solo arcade mode, or multiplay with friends. You can find online opponents, and pit yourself against some of the best Street Fighters in the world, the choice is up to you. I played the arcade mode against the PC, and enjoyed the little mini animations between rounds. I thought that was a nice touch. Playing Blanka, who was always one of my favorites, I thoroughly enjoyed trouncing the competition. I'll admit I haven't actually played the Street Fighter Series since the 90's, but Ultra Street Fighter IV feels like a more modern version of the original, with better graphics, more characters, and new moves. If you enjoy the street fighter series, you should really consider picking this game up.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2013
Updated review, since changes to the Steam client have improved online performance significantly:What's what:The most recent iteration of classic 2D fighting in the Street Fighter universe.  44 characters to play on or off line, and many mechanical intricacies to master, many not covered by the fairly basic tutorials.  Steep learning curve, highly satisfying to master.What's Good: Large roster of well balanced characters, and fully mastering just one can be a serious commitment.  Most players will never run out of new things to tackle and learn. Robust net code for online play, which is always going to have some microseconds of delay compared to offline versus, but for the most part plays fluidly and works great for practice and casual matches. Classic 2D fighting mechanics evolved from SF II that also offers a lot of depth.  Characters can use powerful and flashy ultra combos as a powerful comeback tool.  Make your attacks safe or extend a combo using Focus Attack cancels.  Combos with tight execution require training, but are satisfying to master. Good amount of game modes, from the barebones arcade versus CPU and the feature rich practice mode and character combo trials, to online ranked or casual lobbies and (little used) team battle and 8 player tournaments.What's Bad:  Searching matches based on skill online doesn't work, causing frustration for new players and professionals alike.  Its entirely possible for someone just having installed the game to be matched against an EVO competitor.  USFIV is showing its age visually.  SFIV was never visually advanced, to make sure it ran constant 60 fps on consoles 6 years ago and hasn't seen any visual upgrades since then.  Characters and especially stage backgrounds look quite ugly by today's standards.  Unreasonably strict combo system.  This one's debatable and many will put this as one of the game's strong points.  Most combos are links, meaning they have to be input after an attack animation has ended completely, as opposed to chains, where normal punches and kicks can be cancelled into other attacks.  The frame window to hit these combos can be extremely narrow, often down to 1 or 2 frames precision (Using 60 frames in one second as measuring), meaning even professional players with 5000 hours and more clocked will still sometimes or often miss combo timings.  I'm all for being rewarded for vigilant practice, but combo windows being this rigid is a bit too much, and can be very offputting for newer players to cope with.Summary:While USFIV has strong competition from other fighting games these days, it is still a very good fighting game.  It lacks in tutorials and teaching how to combo and understand the finer technical points however, so new players are going to have to educate themselves outside of the game through wikis and watching a lot of high level play on YouTube or Twitch.  It still enjoys a healthy player base, and despite other games competing for attention in the genre and SF V being in production, I still feel comfortable recommending Ultra Street Fighter IV for players looking to get into a fighting game, or pondering getting the PC version of it.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												USFIV is currently one of the most balanced 1 on 1 2D fighting games with a good fighting system, good amount of characters, moves and game modes. SFIV is a 2D fighting game like most of the previous Street Fighter iterations. It has various characters which increases the chance of some that may catch your fancy. There is even more characters in this ultra edition which is an upgrade to previous SFIV versions. Fighting speed in general is normal compared to other 2D fighters which leaves a good open window for command inputs in-between. This PC version have a decent system settings and controllers compatibility other than x-input (xbox 360/one based) devices and keyboards. For all characters the fighting system has 6 main buttons, blocks are done by holding back, standing, crouching and jumping attacks, throws, dashes, wakeup delay, characters get stunned after certain amount of attacks taken, a 2 stage charge attack (called focus) for each character which strength varies by the duration pressed, characters have special moves and there is extra bar (called super) which has 4 stages (bars) and can be used for having ex version of some specials by using one bar and a super which consumes all 4 bars, there is finishing move bar (called ultra) and each character has 2 ultras which can be selected individually or together, focus then dashing can be used to link some attacks (called focus cancel) and can be used to cancel an active attack for defense and backing up. Attacks are categorized into high, medium, low, overhead, throws, some characters has command throws also and fully charged focus is unblockable. All non-normal attacks will chip the health bar when blocked and can finish a round. All characters have taunts which can be disabled before matches.  Arcade mode acts like story mode with few (1 or more) still images with narration as prologue and a small animated clip as epilogue with rival battles before the boss battle that has special before and in match dialogue. There is versus mode for local or computer battles and also there is computer versus computer matches. Training mode is on normal quality with ability to record actions for the dummy and can be locally controlled or computer controlled and all bars are modifiable, there is challenge mode which is a series of combos for each characters. Online multiplayer is decent now but with less players than the consoles versions as there is no cross platform multiplayer, all online battles have voice chat, there is ranked battles, online training, room battles and tournament like rooms with one active match at a time and all can be open invitation to all or friend invitations and in rooms you can set the number of slots for which type. Online battle can be selected to start and halt current offline matches when found, this applies to arcade and training modes. Online and versus matches replays can be saved although in limited amount and you can watch some matches for high ranking players and some recent replays for others all can be viewed by region or characters. There is a ranking system for your overall points and your character points. You can be unique online by having an icon, a title and a vs screen message and all are pre made. There is different customs for each character and a lot of them are unfortunately available as DLC.Pros:Easy to pick up and learn but hard to master.A very balanced fighting game.Big selection of characters that a lot are totally unique with either English or Japanese voices.All characters versions are available in addition to omega versions.Ability to have different playing styles, strategies.Community, as there is a lot of player made material for every subject.Competitive real life tournaments.Almost endless shelf life for a fighting game.cons:Lackluster arcade/story mode.No Tutorial mode.Stages default BGM is mostly boring except for a few ones.No visual upgrade from 2008.Price is high for an upgrade.DLC is overpriced and cannot be earned in-game.Mastery require too much training for any character.No time attack or survival/endurance modes.Offline and online play variety is limited.Some online modes are almost abandoned.Need to manually adjust some settings in graphics card options outside the game for optimum performance.No official list of all combos or official in-depth guide, also no technical visual assist in training for hitboxes and moves recovery and active frames.Only icons, titles, default custom colors and taunts are rewards for playing.I hope this is a fair review of USFIV on Steam.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												“Yo, this game is so sick”. That is what I said about Ultra Street Fighter 4 after I KO’d one of my many online opponents by mercilessly throwing a beefy Metsu Hadoken right into his chest.  USF4 is, quite possibly, my favorite fighting game that exists to this very day.  This is a strong opinion that I have just given, but please allow me to explain why I feel this way, and why this game may interest you as well.The characters.  USF4 boasts an IMPRESSIVE cast of fighters.  Fans of the older Street Fighter games will see just about all of the old characters they remember and love like Ryu, Chun Li, and Sagat, but the game also throws many new fighters into the mix as well. All together, USF4 offers 44 different fighters to play as.  Can you imagine having 44 different types of delicious pasta given to you at once? I would probably blow up from eating too much.One of the ways that USF4 separates itself from other fighting games is by how accessible it is to fighting game newcomers.  Special move inputs are simple to perform, basic combos are not lengthy or technically demanding, and the pace of the game is much slower than other fighters like Marvel Vs. Capcom or King of Fighters.  This may sound bad for fighting game experts, but USF4 still manages to have a great deal of depth and can be very rewarding for those who put in the work and become godlike.Be warned that this game does not offer much for the single player experience.  It comes with Arcade mode, Training mode, and a Trial mode.  Most players, though, will likely be spending their time playing online trying to become THE STRONGEST IN THE UNIVERSE.  Please keep in mind that many players have had problems with the online thus far. I, PERSONALLY, haven’t had much trouble.  Every now and then, I get a match that lags like a ravenous herd of chunky sea slugs swimming through a rich manure field, HOWEVER, most of the time it runs quite well and I dominate the opponent with my MLG decision making and cunning brilliance.I would like to believe that Street Fighter is the face of fighting games, and luckily, it is also DOWNRIGHT SICK NASTY at what it does.  It’s got tons of memorable characters, stages, and music.  Good visuals and flashy attacks.  An online mode that works great (at least for me) and is very active.  It’s easy for newcomers to enjoy and deep enough for experts to play for hundreds of hours.  To put it simply, USF4 is just like a steaming plate of luxurious lasagna fritta that you never grow tired of.I give Ultra street Fighter 4 a score of “Undisputed Champion of the Makuuchi Sumo Wrestling Division”. Thank you for reading this review.

												Not for casuals. Unless you want to be some guy who sits at home all day playing Street Fighter, you'll never be as good as the other players. The controls are "responsive". Too responsive. Unless you hit that punch button the exact moment you make that quarter circle, you won't get the Hadouken. Once your opponent traps you in their combo, there's no escape. Get this amazing jewel. If you want to have fun, I can recommend Super Smash Brothers. In Super Smash Brothers, you'll have bigger windows of opportunity to escape from combos or make comebacks.The music is great. The main menu music is AWESOME!!! YOU DON'T EVEN KNOW, MAN. content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												As a game, Ultra Street Fighter IV is pretty good. The main thing I look for in a fighting game is gameplay, and USF4 mostly delivers in that respect. However, as a PC port, USF4 is disappointing. That doesn't mean you should write it off, however.USF4 is the final entry in Capcom's line of Street Fighter 4 games. Before this particular entry was developed, Capcom made the stupid decision to saddle its PC ports of Street Fighter IV and Super Street Fighter IV: Arcade Edition with Games For Windows Live. GFWL is DRM that no customer wanted; not only was it unnecessary, but it caused problems for many of the game's paying customers. When Capcom seemingly did the right thing by patching GFWL out of SSF4:AE's PC port, the game's netcode inexplicably took a serious hit. Online play became unreliable at best.Not long after leaving GFWL in the past, Capcom announced that it would develop USF4, and that this update would be developed with Steamworks-based netcode. PC gamers had reason to believe that USF4 would have great online gameplay because it would supposedly be developed from the ground up without any GFWL integration. What PC gamers got instead was simply a patched version of SSF4:AE that still features the same broken netcode. Capcom promised to fix the netcode, butyears later, it has clearly failed to carry out that promise. With Street Fighter 5 having been released, it is unlikely that Capcom will ever fix Street Fighter 4's netcode for the PC.What USF4's sorry state of online play usually amounts to is that internet-based games will be unplayably laggy. This problem occurs even when both of the players are in the same region and have stable internet connections. If you have the fortune of playing online without significant lag, the experience is compromised by the fact that the game does not support voice chat or even native texting.The game isn't a total wash. You can have a good time playing with a buddy who's physically in the same room as you, and the single player arcade mode is mostly fun to play through. For me, the fun stops as soon as I reach Seth, the game's final boss. He's frustratingly cheap and you'll probably struggle to win more than one round against him unless you resort to memorizing his patterns and exploiting their few loopholes in a very contrived manner.Seth battles notwithstanding, USF4's gameplay is solid. However, I don't like Capcom's decision to substite the SF4 games with a focus attack system instead of the parry system that was introduced in Street Fighter III. Although USF4's roster is large, there are many shoto clones, so the gameplay between characters isn't as diverse as your eyes may lead you to believe.As far as graphics go, the characters look pretty good, although Decapre looks way too derivative of Cammy for a first time playable character who was hyped to the moon. (Thankfully, she handles completely differently and does indeed function as a unique character.) Most of the backgrounds are bland and unimaginative, but this has been a problem with every Street Fighter game since Capcom moved on from the Street Fighter II series.I really dislike that game's music, sound effects, and especially its announcer. Sound-wise, the only thing I like about the game is the voice acting.Bottom line, this is a pretty good game, but Capcom should be ashamed for promising to fix SSF4:AE's netcode, only to release this installment and have it suffer from the same problem that Capcom neglected to fix. Mainly for that reason, I disapprove of this port, but not the game itself. People who have friends who can play with them IRL will likely derive the most enjoyment from the PC port of USF4.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2014
												The most balanced fighting game you could ever own, Ultra Street Fighter IV stands as the king of fighters. I'm not one for reviewing games but I wanted to throw in my two cents to encourage you that if you are interested in playing a fighting game, this should be your first if not only choice. While Street Fighter was first born in 1987 and the title may seem like they have rehashed the game overtime, this is definitely not so. Each character has their own unique attributes, strengths, weaknesses, and believe it or not, playstyle. Just like with any game, there is a so called tier-list based off their number of favorable matchups against other characters but for the most part, anyone can win. It is not as up to date graphically but if you appreciate the cartoon/cell shaded style graphics that gives it much more of a fantasy look, it's great. Beautiful soundtrack, sound effects during fights, and add-on content with crazy costumes for characters gives you personality during your fight.The biggest turn off that you may expereince in any fighting game is that you instantly go on-line and expect results. The problem is in a fighting game, being hopeful and mashing buttons just does not bring results (think of grinding in MMOs). While anything can happen in a match, the greatest feeling is learning the ins and outs of the fighting system where combos are difficult enough that when mastered give you a trule feeling of levling up in your gameplay but are not long stretched out button cominations such as Tekken which I myself never was fond of. Online/Offline training mode as well as trials give you the opportunity to grow and develop your timing, spacing of moves, see damage statistics as well as observe your input data to see why the special move you are trying to do is not happening.When it comes to fighting, Street Fighter is very straight forward, with three different levels of punches/kicks, ranging from the lighter faster jab or kick all the way to the stronger but slower hook or roundhouse. While it seems so simple, every character has completely different frame data (meaning that moves do completely different damages and come out faster or slower, some making a character vulnerable to being hit if blocked). This includes characters like Ryu and Ken who everyone knows and thinks they are so similar. While most think that all that is needed to be done is throw Hadoukens or mash special moves to win, this is just not the case. In this generation of gaming, it is crucial that you fight with your mind. Not being able to defend yourself results in very fast knockouts. What I love personally about this is that since every character is different, you start to learn which characters are aggressive, defensive, controling certain spaces, etc. This aids in creating a unqiue experience with every character you play. The community for this game itself is very focused on the growth of players though just like any game, you will have trollers. It's inevitable. Great replay channel usage (download and upload as well as linking to Youtube.) Split-screen play as well which is a rare commodity in this day and age.The only downside about Street Fighter is that on PC (While I wouldn't consider it a precise downside but for those that don't do reserach, it will be), playing online optimized will require to setup your PC in a specific way. The game is made to run at 60FPS for second without too much enhancement. Failing to run it properly will keep you from being able to perform combos correctly which of how frame precise button presses are (though this is with just about any fighting game). The preferred method of running the game includes the following settings:- Enable v-sync and triple buffering for Ultra Street Fighter IV in your nVidia Control Panel or ATI Control Center (This fixes screen tearing and allows a 60fps without over-smoothing the game to cause issues with button presses- In-game run whatever resolution you can comfortably and disable V-Sync in game, and put Frame Rate to "Fixed."By doing this, it will be running close to if not mimicing the arcade version in terms of fluency.With achievements, difficult to master, great online experience, and depth, this is THE fighting game you will not want to pass up.PROS-------------+Replay value+Character Roster  (44 Characters)+Character creativity / uniqueness+Controls+Online community+Gameplay Depth / Mechanics+Soundtrack+Graphically beautifulCONS_________- PC version not as optimized as console. Requires tweaking for the best experience.Welcome to the community if you buy it! Enjoy!

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												(Too long; Didn't read at the bottom)Okay, yeah, you know what, there's a massive issue when you prefer Games for Windows Live...Okay sure, it's a fun fighting game for all players, young, old, beginner or master and it's easy to learn with a different variety of characters, costumes, colours, stages and moves... But what's not fun is getting absolutely destroyed because of the online of this game.Steam has completely ruined online for this game, it jitters constantly which slows the game down and makes it literally impossible to do a special move, but then what happens? It's A-Okay! Finally the lag is over!.... For 5 seconds then proceeds to jitter more, I don't know if this is just the netcode, my internet connection (which is perfect, I have no issues on any other version on this game), or my computer (which is a beast and runs anything I make it run on the highest graphics possible) but it's seriously broken, like, actually broken.On the other hand, some say that the netcode is fine with no issues, but these people who have told me that the netcode is fine have over 40mbps download and 10mbps upload speeds (no surprise there is there.) So what about the people who can't get fibre optic connectivity? We just can't play, at all.Games for Windows Live was a GODSEND compared to this broken hunk of junk, GFWL is active on multiple games *cough* Street Fighter x Tekken *cough* UMK3 *cough* so why can't we bring it back? It was infinitely better than this, sure we sometimes got some problems with connections, but that was mainly down to a persons internet speeds and connectivity, NOT broken netcode... I seriously pray for Games for Windows Live to make a return, at least that worked correctly!In conclusion, I recommend it for people who want a fun OFFLINE fighting game, or for people who want to practice without the need of a console, but unless you have very fast internet speeds, I wouldn't recommend investing time going into Ranked Mode.TL;DR: Broken netcode, not fun, dropping combos, fun game offline for the whole family, praying for GFWL to come back, not recommended online, recommended for offline use.

												A pretty great starting point to get into fighting games. Easy to pick up but incredibly difficult to master. It's like a game of chess, you know how everything works, but making it so it all fits together in execution is where you will need to practice and get better at. Lots of different characters that play differently and have different playstyles, everyone's got their favorites. Definitely worth picking up on a sale, make sure to get THIS version of the game if you want the full experience. Especially if you're holding off for Street Fighter 5.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												What can I say, this game had a REALLY good run. 2008 to 2016 is pretty damn good. This game has so many good memories for me. I remember the time when my uncle had pre-ordered vanilla SFIV for the PS3 and I wanted to play it so bad because the commercials made that game look HYPE AS♥♥♥♥♥♥ heh, good times those were. Anyways, this game has a HUGE roster of characters at this point and is very easy to get into, however at some point you will get the urge to become better at this game, that's where you'll get frustrated. Trust me, this game can be a ♥♥♥♥♥ to master, but once you have all the hard stuff down like, FADCs, solid combos (because this game has 1 frame links), footsies, zoning and ESPECIALLY the mind games, you'll be an excellent player. So do I recommend this game? OF COURSE! It's an amazing game. However, the entire reason why I decided to share a little memory of my past with this game was because I'm honestly kind of bored of it and moving on to SFV. Why move on to SFV? Well, for many people the answer is "because it's the new Street Fighter, DUH!", but personally for me It's because it's been a while since a Street Fighter game has felt like the classics and SFV really brings that back, but if you're new to the Street Fighter series I can guarantee you that this game will be a hell of a lot of fun when you first get your hands on it.2017 edit: Forget what I said about Street Fighter V this game is still a ton better than that trash.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												It doesn't matter if you good or bad at fighting games. I am not good-at-all at it but Ultra Street Fighter IV (USFIV) is clearly the only fighting game that make me want to be better at it. This game is awesome. Really, it is. It's also a great game if you're really strong at fighting games of course don't worry.Let's make a list.Pros ;+ Controls ; You have a couple of choice, arcade controller (the best), the XBOX or basic controller (the good) and the keyboard (the not-so-good). I am playing on keyboard and Capcom show us that it's possible to play with a keyboard at Street Fighter. + Ambiance ; One of the most intense and greatest ambiance I ever saw in a videogame. + Sound ; With quality voice acting and sounds, it won't hurt your ears and it keep the great ambiance.+ Music ; I am not into Techno music but this game have clearly great musics that fit every situations.+ Graphism ; Colorful and awesome. The characters animations were really polished and all the extra effects look perfect.+ Storyline ; Yes, there is a storyline for EVERY SINGLE CHARACTER in the Arcade mode. Every character have their own theme, rivals, boss and cutscene (let's not forget about the animation that starts at the begining of a fight too.)+ Character choice ; There is a lot of playable characters which made the Street Fighter Universe so great. Make your choice. Play only with your special someone or try'em all.+ Character customization ; You can change the color of your character clothes and even changing them if you have the correct DLC of course.+ Difficulty ; There not only Easy Medium and Hard there is like 10 differents difficulties. You just need to pick-up the one that fits you which make this game perfect for Not-good players or Super strong players.+ 2 Players party ; Of course, why in the world would you not being able to play with your (real-life) friend at a Street Fighter game?+ Training and Challenge Mode ; Those are great and can really help you to figure out some new tricks for your favorite character.Cons ;- Online ; No much people and most of them are smurfs and people that is playing fighting games from the time they're 5. No actual rookie, initiated, causual or even intermediate players. Only brainless phycos that absolutely need to play with a stick. - Online lag ; Like the online matchmaking isn't already that hard. There is a serious problem about the lags in this game.- Team Match ; It looks interesting, but I was never able to find a single server.- DLCs ; It bring great customization possibilities but it's expensive. Like 5€ for 4~5 outfits.- Difficulty at the end of the Arcade Mode ; When you're going for the boss it will be really, really, really harder that the other folks you just met ealier. It can be really frustrating sometimes.- Achievements difficulty ; Why Capcom, why ? These achivements are super hard, really.TL;DROverall, this is great. Really. But don't bet on the Online mode, it's not nice. However the Arcade and Versus Mode are awesome. You will really have fun by playing this game. It worth the price, definitly→ 89/100

content:
Posted: April 12, 2014
												The king of the hill. The epitomy in fighting games. Super Street Fighter 4 Arcade Edition is continuing the success of the Street Fighter franchise that started and "created" the fighting genre as we know it today.Beautiful 2D graphics, amazing soundtrack and all the classic moves we learned while playing in the local arcades while being young. Its all back better, faster, harder, stronger. With a huge cast of characters for all tastes, a plethora of different moves and combos and a good online battle system which is lag free most of the time. SSF4 AE is super enjoyable for everyone, even those who prefer the offline game or their living room fighting with friends and having a blast. For those that money isn't an issue, or for those that really want to focus on the game i recommend to buy an arcade fighting stick as a controller. The experience is trully unique.The learning curve for the more advance technics might be a bit steep for new players that try the genre for the first time, but the fighting is community is insanely active and offer great assistance to everyone that is willing to ask or look for it.The only con i found personally is that the tutorial on the mechanics of the game is nonexistant so you have to figure yourself or watch one of the many tutorials out there of how the game actually works.I recommend it 100% to everyone that wants to start the fighting genre, veterans of the kind are already playing it the review isn' t for them, its the perfect game to be initiated to fighting games.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												SSFIVAE is a 2.5D fighting game that has a lot of different characters, all with unique playstyles and moves.Gameplay: The gameplay is great; there's alot of special attacks and unique attacks specific to each character, combos are difficult but satisfying, and playing on the keyboard is pretty tough so I would suggest getting a controller to play.Content: SSFIVAE has an Arcade mode which has a cutscene at the beginning, a series of matches against AI or a second player, 2 minigames built in, then a cutscene about specific rival, you face the rival, then you face Seth: the game's 'boss'. There are 24 specific trials to each character which make you do special moves and combos that allow you to train and get better with a character.Multiplayer: For the most part, the multiplayer is smooth, fast, and rarely has lag. Occasionaly you will get put up against someone that has network problems but you can always back out before you go into a match. There are 4 gamemodes in the multiplayer: ranked match, endless match, team battle, and tournament. In a ranked match, you will gain and lose player points(points specific to your profile) and battle points(points specific to a character). The PP and BP will be visible to the other people in a lobby/match with you. The multiplayer also goes through GFWL(Games for Windows Live), which most people don't like, but I've heard that its shutting down soon, so don't worry.Visuals and Audio: The graphics are great, it has a cartoony style to it and the characters have a cool black outline on them. The maps are really cool, and they all have animations to them(besides the training stage). The sounds are really good aswell,  there's great voice acting, but occasionally the map music gets a little repetitive.Overall I would recommend this to anyone. 9/10

content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												One of the best fighting game of this generation. Although the entrance may be a bit harsh and unforgiving for beginner fighters since the learning curve is pretty stiff, you're still gonna have a blast of fun button mashing with your friends. A great game for a sleep over party where you can casually beat up each other till the sun rise :DBut when you got a hang of the basics and want to discover futher, this is where the true fun begin: this game offers unlimited type of playstyles to learn, depends on your character of choice: grappler, zoner, defensive charger, offensive rush-down...and many more. I spent almost 3 and a half years playing this game with mostly one character and still got a lot to learn from! The soundtrack is amazing, Indestructible and Sakura themes are my personal favourites, although all other themes are awesome too. In my experience, the game is best enjoyable when playing with friends offline, such as the arcade or a net cafe rather playing it alone with AI and online opponents. So go ahead and join your nearest Street Fighter local community!
