content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												This game is a joke! It's not possible to effectively play it with a keyboard and it does not recognize a gamepad. In order to play it with a gamepad it requires to switch windows with Alt+Tab and then switch back to the game again. While playing with a keyboard, some characters are not moving back and forth, and it's almost impossible to perform special moves. Besides, special moves do not cause substantial damage. Taking into account the time you need to spend on pressing special combination, it's better to just stick with the combos. The story and character lines are too cheesy even for a fighting game. The gameplay itself is boring. I feel really disappointed with this game, although it was one my favourite titles back in the days of 8-bit consoles.Full price, costs of upgrade, DLCs and costumes are a steal. Capcom is just exploiting the popularity of the title.My only comfort is that I bought USFIV with 75% discount. It's still not worth it.Overall rating: 4/10.If you want a decent fighting game, go get "Mortal Kombat Komplete Edition" or "Injustice: Gods Among Us" during sales time. It has much more to offer for a lower price. Or, if you want something from Street Fighter, go try Street Fighter X Tekken, but it's good only because it has Tekken characters in it. Oh, Capcom, please don't go down that road Nintendo did. Some of your other titles are really great, but if you'll keep exploiting the glory of past days, you'll loose your customers. Atleast in the West.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2015
												Recommended! If you're looking for a warm-up to Street Fighter V then here is your chance.If you're a long term fan of the Street Fighter franchise, then SF4 should be familiar to you - and an enjoyable experience.Certain things have changed in ths version of SF4 however;1/ You will fnd fireballs less effective (aka zoning)2/ Being able to 'get in' on people significantly easier (some call it 'rushdown')Those two points makes life easier for low to intermediate players making the game enjoyable without investing hundreds of hours into the game to 'get good to win'. Long story short, you can probably win more games with less time invested than older versions of SF4 and have fun with it. I'm crusty and old and enjoyed SF4 and SSF4 more. :) but can still extract some fun out of Ultra SF4!

content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
												This game has a small, teeny tiny learning curve. At first you will fight street and street will always win. BUT don't get discouraged, if you spend some time (1-3 minutes for most) learning to fight street you will always win 100% of the time. If you keep on fight streeting you will become fight streeter pro umehara daigo senpai 840 double blaze it momochi san topanga SS+ league double mustard 10k PP jack of all trades, and MASTER of all 44 characters, over the course of  5~ hours game time give or take 30 minutes. All you have to do is hit the opponent until their life runs out its really easy.Fighting games have an amount of depth that is very rewarding for a committed player, and so does this game. If you get past the learning curve you will be enjoying fighting games for a very long time.*EDIT* It's 2016 and SFV is out, get this instead.

I absolutely love the Street Fighter 4 games.  I thought Capcom may have been done with the 3D fighter realm after the Street Fighter Ex games, but nope! content:
Posted: July 12, 2012
												It took a while, but I think it's now safe to say this is the definitive version of Street Fighter 4. It had some ups and downs but the community is still strong in this 6+ year old game. Ultra brings with it a slew of buffs and nerfs of all the characters, 5 new characters ( 4 carried over from SFxT) and more costumes than you could possibly have any use for.As the basis for most if not all 2d fighters in the last decade or so, you wont go far wrong choosing USFIV as a first forrey into the world of Fighting games. Intimidating at first, but you will be hadoken'ing and shoryuken'ing in no time at all. Extensive trials for each character and even an online training mode so you can practice with your friends makes it even easier to pick up for first timers.A game that is easy to pick up but takes time to master. In my opinion, if you are willing to put some time and practice into it, this games value far exceeds the price of admission.

												This game has a small, teeny tiny learning curve. At first you will fight street and street will always win. BUT don't get discouraged, if you spend some time (1-3 minutes for most) learning to fight street you will always win 100% of the time. If you keep on fight streeting you will become fight streeter pro umehara daigo senpai 840 double blaze it momochi san topanga SS+ league double mustard 10k PP jack of all trades, and MASTER of all 44 characters, over the course of  5~ hours game time give or take 30 minutes. All you have to do is hit the opponent until their life runs out its really easy.Fighting games have an amount of depth that is very rewarding for a committed player, and so does this game. If you get past the learning curve you will be enjoying fighting games for a very long time.*EDIT* It's 2016 and SFV is out, get this instead.

If you're looking for a warm-up to Street Fighter V then here is your chance.If you're a long term fan of the Street Fighter franchise, then SF4 should be familiar to you - and an enjoyable experience.Certain things have changed in ths version of SF4 however;1/ You will fnd fireballs less effective (aka zoning)2/ Being able to 'get in' on people significantly easier (some call it 'rushdown')Those two points makes life easier for low to intermediate players making the game enjoyable without investing hundreds of hours into the game to 'get good to win'. I'm crusty and old and enjoyed SF4 and SSF4 more. :) but can still extract some fun out of Ultra SF4!

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												If you played Street fighter, or any of its many clones, this game should be no problem getting right into as long as you play casually.  But if you expecting to be playing online against experienced player and winning, you might want to take time practicing and watching tutorials online.  That’s if you can get a decent connection with other players.  That’s my main gripe.  Everything appears to be fine with full green bars, but as soon as the match starts, it’s like some time wizard slows everything down as you desperately try to block a string of unconnected attacks.  And it appears that many online have mastered exploiting the lag fest with repetitive moves that make blocking seem impossible.  Best bet is playing against friends you know have good connections, which will limit you to non ranked matches, but who cares.  Overall, it’s good fighting game with a substandard online matchmaking component.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												I'm a long time Street Fighter fan and started playing the game on the Super Nintendo when I was a little child around 11 years of age.The game came as a package with the console and I was drooling over the cartridge's cover which looked so much cooler than the other variant sporting the Super Mario World cartridge, so I was making up stuff about what this game would be going to be like and who this Hulk-esque looking beast was.My imagination was wrong, because even the imagination of a 11-year old boy could not fathom the awesomeness that was Street Fighter II: The World Warrior.In Germany where I come from, there sadly was never an arcade culture, since our law sees every machine you throw money into as gambling and that is strictly prohibited to minors.That still did not stop me to visit my friends and play the game with them, competing with each other and dreaming about how cool it would be if you could play with people from around world and visit tournaments and stuff.Sooner or later my friends quit playing the game, either out of disinterest or because they felt it was too much effort to try keeping up with me.Now I'm coming closer to the point I am trying to make.See fighting games are pretty much worthless as single player experiences. You simply NEED to play these games with human competition, no matter how well-crafted the single player experience may be, in the end everything boils down to multiplayer.When SFIV was finally released I first chose to ignore it, since I did not own a console at that time, but the thought that you could finally play this amazing game against other people from around the world was intriguing to say the least.Couple of years later I saw the game in a Steam Sale and picked it up, had tons of fun with it, even though the Games For Windows Live-Online was garbage by my standards (I come from playing DotA, Blizzard titles and Dota 2, so my online standards are pretty damn high), it did the job good enough for me to keep playing and stay interested.Now it has been 3 month since Super Street Fighter 4: AE2012 was ported to Steamworks and it completely broke online play for a lot of people. I personally have to set my computer to DMZ in my router in order to be able to play the game properly and it still lags horribly at least once a match, the menus start lagging as well and it's generally a pain in the butt playing the game.When Ultra Street Fighter 4 hit the stores, I thought Capcom had been working on fixing these problem for the past couple of month and are now ready to patch it along with the upgrade.Plot Twist:Turns out they did not do jack♥♥♥♥♥♥ despite their forum posts saying they were aware of the problem and working on it, they did not do anything and even had the nerve to post the same stuff that they already did with the AE transition, which was "We are aware of the problem and we are going to fix it".I will try to come to an end here in my clumsy try to make a game review.Bottom line for me is that if you are not living in Arcade America/Japan and you do not know anyone around you who regularly plays Ultra Street Fighter 4, then do not bother with this game since Capcom does not give a single fart about you and chances are that you will not be able to play this game with anyone else but yourself.The game itself is well-designed maybe a bit buggy overall but it is a good entry to the Street Fighter series and tons of fun, ultimately I decide against recommending this game, since the online multiplayer is a major selling point, not only for me but for most people, and since it does not work like intended, I will refrain from telling anyone to buy it.UPDATE:As of the 03.30.2015, this game is actually playable online, to the same extend that GFWL was and XBox Live is.Go ahead and buy it, if you're looking for a rather defensive but well-made Street Fighter game.The game has its downsides of course, but it's still Street Fighter and a lot of fun to play.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Street Fighter IV is the sole reason why fighting games made a comeback when they were at the edge of fading away. If you ask anyone who takes fighting games seriously this game is incredibly important and obviously has a huge following. Its greatest strengths come in finding a way to reintroduce characters from previous games in a setting that dosent screw the story up as bad as SF3 did and at the same time maintain a presentation that has become iconic since its initial release. This game has had WAY too many re-releases in forms of newer versions that that includes the most recent update "ULTRA Street Fighter IV" coming out early next year, but obviously if this game has been going strong for THIS LONG, it must be doing something right. Now, from my own personal opinion, i think a good number of the "new" characters they tried to introduce alongside the classic roster dont really have the same magic as the classics, especially El fuerte and Rufus, but that might just be me. Either way, this game is worth the time and money if you intend on buckling down and seriously practicing and playing as much online and local competition as possible. The online is good, netcode is far better than most PC fighters we get with the exception of GGPO netcode games. I suppose in a way, this game is great for both beginners who get exposure to many of the best classic characters without having to play the older games and its worthy of getting the attention of seasoned veterans. If you look at SFIV's track record, you can argue, but you wont get far. 9/10

												I would recmmend this game, just not for Steam. The reasons? since GFWL was removed from SSFIV the game has no longer worked properly for lot's of people (myself included) due to the netcode. This messed with the fps (even in single player) because of a massive memory leak which was fixed by the community and not Capcom. The second problem with SSFIV was the online matchmaking was just a massive lag-fest again because of the bad netcode. How did Capcom respond to fixing SSFIV? They decided to just release the USFIV DLC knowing about all the problems that were present with SSFIV. So basically the one thing most people complained about (GFWL) was actually the only thing saving this game from a disaster. Capcom has a bad habit of releasing a broken game then letting the community know "We are aware of the situation" without actually fixing anything, then abandoning the game to focus on money grabbing from their next game (DR3 is also a broken mess).

content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												This game plays like TOTAL @$$. The online has been destroyed by Steamworks and is almost entirely unplayable. The bars used to let you know your connection to your opponent are useless. Ive had numerous matches that showed full bars but were full of latency issues causing huge frame drops and inputs to come out late or not at all. This is disappointing since the GWL was a lot more balanced. But Capcom made the game so I can't blame it all on steam, especially since even the offline seems to suffer from stability issues. Was such a waste of money to upgrade. I'd rather have spent the money on a decent indy game. But alas Crapcom did it again. They tricked me into buying rehashed garbage put into a shiny new package that barely runs. I've heard the Xbox 360 version is the more stable one but even it has its problems. content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												Super Street Fighter IV does an amazing job of serving lapsed Street Fighter players who remember the days of jump hard kick into sweep combos and fireball wars while providing enough breadth and depth to entertain fighting game veterans.I fell into the former category until this game drew me in; it reinvigorated the genre for me and, alongside countless others, I tried to learn the genre "properly" for the first time. 3000+ hours later I'm still obsessed with it, playing SSFIV, reading about SSFIV, watching SSFIV matches but more than that I've also developed a greater appreciation for three decades worth of fighting games of the past.Super Street Fighter IV is excellent and terrifying and addictive and fun. A wonderful stepping-stone on your way to divorce.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												Street Fighter has been the quintessential fighting game series since Street Fighter 2 and with Street Fighter 4 that title is staying put.The Street Fighter mechanics haven't changed much since SF2 but it really doesn't matter.  The game is still fun whether you're playing it for the first time since SF2 or at a much higher level.  Added modes such as the Trials, where it teaches you how to perform any characters combos, and a training mode where you can record the computer's movements and play them back are terrific tools.The game is superbly balanced and as long as you know the fundamentals, you'll have a fighting chance with any character you choose.  The fact that they brought back all 8 characters from the original SF2 with only minor differences to fight against newer, much more complex characters further proves how balanced this game really is.  The game has a whopping 39 character cast that will see 5 more additions with the next expansion set to release in relatively soon.Visually the game is still great to look at. The art style is reminiscent of old Japanese calligraphy, which they go crazy with when a character lands an Ultra attack.  Going with non-photogenic art direction makes any game’s graphics longer lasting.After 4 years Street Fighter 4 is still the most popular fighting game out there.  With its giant all-star cast, and finely tuned fight system one has to wonder if this series has anywhere else to go.  It’s nice to see Capcom experiment a little with games like Marvel vs Capcom and Street Fighter X Tekken but Street Fighter 4 is still THE fighting game.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2016
												SFIV is an amazing 2 player fighting game.  If you understand how to do the basics, like a fireball, dragon punch, wirlwind kick, etc, the game is almost flawless with a splash of supers and ultra combos!  I havent had as much fun with a fighting game (save Killer Instinct) as I have with this game.  It is truly awesome.That said, if you have issues performing the basic moves, you may not end up getting all that much out of the game.  For me, its hard to imagine anyone that can't do the basic moves which can be applied to pretty much every other fighter on the roster.  And there are a TON of fighters to choose from.  But not being able to do basic moves would make the game rather dull.If your into fighting games, you probably already own this game but if your new to Street Fighter and want a solid game to even just start learning, I would highly recommend this game.  There also isnt any shortage of DLC for the game, though most of it are costumes which is not needed but fun to have.

												Seriously the best purchase I have ever made.   After all of this game play, it's difficult to explain how it still has an allure for me.  Most games I have one playthrough and that's it, but not with this game. I still lose quite a bit in this game, but I think that's what keeps on bringing me back, because I have gotten better over time.  It is a really deep game that requires you to anticipate the patterns of you opponent, and then execute flawless combos.  With time, the combos become natural, and you will slowly develop more skill.  Don't be afraid to get your♥♥♥♥♥handed to you, because it will happen.  All you can do is learn from it and then come back stronger.  Amazing game.  Best Steam Purchase Ever.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												One on one competition at it's finest. No teams to fall back on or get in the way. No killstreaks. No map advantage. No gear. No excuses. Super Street Fighter IV is the finest current game that the fighting game genre has to offer. With remarkably deep mechanics, great balance, and a seemingly limitless skill cieling, it's obvious why that after 4+ years, the latest iteration of Street Fighter 4 is still the most played fighting game out there these days. Button mashers beware, you'll get nowhere online against the people that play this game. You'll get your♥♥♥♥♥kicked relentlessly until you learn to kick back, but earning that clutch victory against a skilled opponent is one of the most satisfying feelings in all of multiplayer gaming. For those that want a truly competitive experience, I really can't reccommend any game as highly as this. That is, as long as you're ready to rise to the challenge. It will be a very long and brutal road to becoming a good player in a game like this.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												One of the best modern fighting games out there. Don't be ignorant about the online ranked match lag. It isnt the game's fault, it's steam's. Most of the time, it's pretty decent any way. Now to the actual game.Pros:-Deep gameplay you would expect from a Street Fighter title-One of the best rosters the series has ever seen-Very ballanced game, matchups dont get any worse than 3-7, and there aren't many 3-7's-Simple enough for a beginner, complex enough for the fighting game godsCons:-The sound quality of the in-game chat is really bad-Community isnt very big (this game is played mostly by console players)Misc. Comments:-Best played on an arcade stick, but a standard game pad will suffice-Players on steam aren't as good as the players on console (For example, I would consider a player with up to 500PP "free" on console, but on steam, i would consider a player with up to 900PP "free"-Patience is your greatest weapon in this game-There is a ton of input leniency (it's good and bad, depends on the situation)Hence, I would highly recomend this game to any one, even if you aren't really a fan of fighters. This one is a ton of fun. I have about 116 hours on steam, and another 200 hours on console invested into this game. I dont regret a single second of it.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												Capcom has no love for PC The netcode has been broken for half a year while they focus on releasing more and more costume packs. There are a great many issues that have been well known for years like controller swap in arcade mode or having to specify what controller you're using every time you go to the character select screen in VS mode. Capcom has chosen to ignore every single issue while they put more and more resources into the sort of outfits that only a 5 year old would think is cool (swimming outfits from 100 years ago and fury outfits so the characters look like they're going to a Halloween party). Consols get all updates and DLC long before PC, and when we do finally get them they're usually broken. As of now I could not recommend anyone buy anything Capcom on PC. They treat us like a red headed step-child that's lucky to get any attention at all. Even if Capcom decided to snap out of their PC hate today it would take years before they reorganized the company in a way that made PC anything but a third wheel. If you want a good fighter for PC check out SkullGirls. Even if it's not the sort of aesthetic you prefer their developers have proven that they actually care about PC. They actually listen to what players complain about, patch the game regularly, and do not slow things down for consols. They should serve as a model for any company wanting to release fighting games on PC. I'm willing to bet Capcom will release a costume pack with all the characters in pink tutus long before they take any complaints seriously.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												Most of us could never forget those local arcades even if we wanted to. The smoke, the loud cheesy music, and the nasty Cheetos residue that seemed to be on every joystick. Street Fighter 4 (in this case Ultra Street Fighter 4, not to be confused with the other 4 iterations) keeps this spirit alive in arguably the most classic fighting franchise in history, with fresh coats of paint and brand new systems. Being a 6 button fighter, I'd imagine you already own a PC compatible arcade stick or a different pad if you so prefer. Unless you want eternal carpal tunnel or feel the need to flex your masochistic man-boobs, avoid using the keyboard at all costs.Most reviews will say "DON'T EVER BUY THIS GAME EVER EVER CUZ LAAAGGG :((((" and they honestly have somewhat of a point. It's difficult to improve at such a difficult game without fighting others online - one of the most demanding online games to date that requires near perfect execution, which is damn near impossible in some of the servers you get set into during a ranked match. As long as you aren't playing on a toaster, this game will run perfectly fine for all other modes including 2 player local versus. But let's face it, at least 80% of your playtime will be in the training room against an auto-blocking Abel. Let's face it, he has the most consistent hitbox, or maybe you just hate the French. All in all, USF4 is that arcade experience we've always known and loved, but excluding those guys who don't shower and wear Etnies. What a bonus! Comes packed with great content and all them #alternateskinzzz. If Capcom can get their♥♥♥♥♥♥together with the netcode, there's absolutely no reason for a fighting game enthusiast to not pick this title up on the genetically superior platform.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												Capcom has no love for PC The netcode has been broken for half a year while they focus on releasing more and more costume packs. There are a great many issues that have been well known for years like controller swap in arcade mode or having to specify what controller you're using every time you go to the character select screen in VS mode. Capcom has chosen to ignore every single issue while they put more and more resources into the sort of outfits that only a 5 year old would think is cool (swimming outfits from 100 years ago and fury outfits so the characters look like they're going to a Halloween party). Consols get all updates and DLC long before PC, and when we do finally get them they're usually broken. As of now I could not recommend anyone buy anything Capcom on PC. They treat us like a red headed step-child that's lucky to get any attention at all. Even if Capcom decided to snap out of their PC hate today it would take years before they reorganized the company in a way that made PC anything but a third wheel. If you want a good fighter for PC check out SkullGirls. Even if it's not the sort of aesthetic you prefer their developers have proven that they actually care about PC. They actually listen to what players complain about, patch the game regularly, and do not slow things down for consols. They should serve as a model for any company wanting to release fighting games on PC. I'm willing to bet Capcom will release a costume pack with all the characters in pink tutus long before they take any complaints seriously.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												This is a very hard game to review under Steam's system of recommended versus not recommended. Even though I have it set to not recommended, I plan on continuing to play this game extensively. I also think it's a very well made game with extremely tight balance. Yes, even Dan is playable in this game (though still not great, by design).If you're a fighting game enthusiast, then odds are you already own this game. If you don't, and you really are into fighting games, then get it. I fully recommend it, just be aware that this game is much slower paced than most 2d fighters. Combos tend to be short and difficult to execute, as opposed to being long and fairly easy. Other than that, there's nothing here that should be out of the ordinary to you.For everyone else... this is not a game you can simply pick up and begin playing. The single player content is as bare bones as could be, providing a training mode, a short arcade mode, and then a series of trials for every character. I'll get to the trials in a moment.Quite simply, this game does not teach you anything. It does not delicately introduce you to its mechanics and help you learn. If you want to play this game, you must dedicate yourself to it or else you're basically throwing your money away. I've played a lot of fighting games, especially in the Soul Calibur, Smash and Marvel vs Capcom series, and this game is the single most prohibitavely difficult game to begin playing of any of them. The trials I mentioned, while they do help you learn some things about your chosen character, there's nothing in the game that teaches you about the core fundamentals of how to play it.At this point, I've spent more time practicing, studying (using online research, as again there's not much here that will teach you on its own) and learning this game than any other I've ever played. That includes things traditionally considered hard to learn, such as MOBAs like Dota 2. In fact I'd probably guess I've spent as much time with this game trying to learn it as I spent with the majority of the college classes I took when I was still in school. I am not exaggerating in the slightest. And after all that, I still lose the vast majority of the time, despite the fact I have fairly good win percentages in other fighting games. Or at the least, not as crushingly awful as my current 15ish to 120ish win:loss ratio.You're also probably going to want to buy a specialized controller for it, like a Madkatz Fightpad or an arcade stick (and good arcade sticks cost as much as some tablets, keep in mind). You can play it with a keyboard or a regular controller, and there are a small number of really good keyboard warriors, but I think it's generally accepted that these methods are harder than playing with a stick or a specialized fightpad controller.And that's really why I have to set this game as not recommended, despite the fact I love it. It's entirely unacceptable that I am currently almost 70 hours played after doing online research since the game does almost nothing to teach you anything itself, and I still barely understand what's going on. At this point I'm just continuing to play it because I'm just starting to reach the point where I don't feel completely lost and overwhelmed, but the satisfaction I get out of it is about the same as if I had just booted up my Wii U and played Smash Brothers instead, a game which is far more accessable.If you have a true commitment to learning this game, and you don't mind getting utterly crushed for an extensive amount of time and buying extra peripherals just to play it, then go ahead and get it. Also, pick Guile or Ryu for the first little while, as those characters are made to help new players learn the game while still being powerful at high skill levels. Pick Ryu if you like quarter circle characters, or Guile if you like charge characters... and if you don't know what a charge character is, look it up, because the game won't tell you. For everyone else, save your money and look elsewhere. You will just get frustrated and feel like you wasted your time.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												***This review is intended for people who are newer or unfamiliar with fighters. If you're an experienced fighting game player you probably already know why you love or hate this game!***This is the gold standard for fighting games. No fighter out there is more balanced, rewards fundamentals and guesses/reads more intelligently, or has the staying power of USF4.The balance is so impressive. So often, fighting games eventually mature to the point where people have found the 2-3 most powerful characters and the rest of the cast is ignored. In USF4 there are definitely characters considered better than others, but the "top tier" consists of almost a dozen characters, and every single character of the 40+ in the game, even the "low tier" is extremely viable.This game will force you to play more solidly than a lot of other fighters. Button mashers beware - you may take a few rounds now and then but this game is designed to punish you HARD. In fact, if you're new at this, THIS GAME AND EVERYONE WHO PLAYS IT WILL KICK YOUR♥♥♥♥♥ It will stay that way for probably at least 100 hours in. And even then, the skill ceiling is practically infinite. When I bought Street Fighter 4: AE I knew nothing about fighting games. 1400 hours later I'm finally at a level where I'd consder myself "decent". On the way, I've discovered everything about what makes fighters an intelligent, deep, addicting, and all around amazing genre, way beyond what I had ever imagined. It's a genre that can make you feel the raw sting of defeat (where unlike in MOBAs, you only have yourself to blame) and the consequent high of a hard-won victory. There is a definite lack of in-game resources for learning, so you'll start off stuck in a trench of sorts. You'll have to spend a long time reading up online and practicing to get acclamated to the game systems, which to some may seem archaic at times (1 frame links are a common source of frustration). But if you can fight through this and make it out of this phase you'll be on a journey to discover what makes fighting games truly amazing.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
Street fighter 4 is largely regarded as being the current centrepiece of the fighter genre, this is perhaps due to the fact that it is essentially an updated and carefully expanded version of Street Fighter 2 – the game that in many respects defined the genre. The motions and inputs required to perform moves are often daunting to players unfamiliar with fighting games and accustomed to the streamlined, immersive control schemes of today's FPS games and platformers, where pressing the 'right buttons' isn't really a factor you have to worry about. This may be in part the reason why Street fighter has a smaller (but no less passionate) following than the big MOBA, RTS and FPS games despite being such a rich and strategic game. Because to access that part of the game where you need to consider timing, reading, predicting, matchups etc you must first be able to pull off the moves and subsequent combos reliably, a process that can be a barrier to new players.But at the same time this is what makes Street fighter so great. The controller motions and inputs and the special attacks they yield have a sense of logic to them. 'Shoto' characters launch most of their special moves by timing an attack at the end of a quarter circle movement with the joystick. 'Charge' characters achieve their special moves by momentarily holding the joystick in one direction and then pressing an attack as they move it in the opposite. Grappling characters launch devastating throws and slams by doing entire loops with the joystick just before they attack, and Special and Ultra moves are done by pulling off really quick 'double movements' and by pressing down three buttons at once. The inputs for moves don't feel like arbitrary sequences or codes but rather appropriate movements. This sort of gameplay, which has it's roots in the video game Arcade, has a genuinely tactile quality to it that lends itself to representing fighting and martial arts.On top of that Street Fighter boasts some of the most iconic video game characters of all time who are conceptually inseparable from their signature special moves. In summary, Street Fighter is to many, including myself, the definitive 2D fighting game franchise and Street fighter 4 ULTRA with it's insane roster of 44 distinct playable characters is the best version to date.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
												Disclaimer: I'm awful at this game, thus I spend a lot of time angry at it.But I think the reason I dislike it is some ratio of that, the fact that the game just feels clunky, stiff and robotic, and that the AI cheats. Hard to pinpoint what ratio that really is.The presentation is alright. The 3D models animate pretty well and all, but eh, 2D was better and had much more personality. I wish everybody didn't yell so many quips in mid-combat. Voice acting mainly ranges from unremarkable to bad, with a few exceptions. Music is decent across the board and actually sometimes pretty excellent.Upgrading from Super to Ultra earns you five new (read: mostly rehashed from SFxTK) characters and a handful of new (read: mostly rehashed from SFxTK) stages. Also probably some rebalancing or whatever that most players will never notice. I gotta admit I really like Rolento though. And I do appreciate the sheer volume of characters.I...ugh. This game just went so far backwards from SF3 and SFA3. Seems like every action in the game imposes a quarter-second or more delay on anything else you do. I mean I don't -hate- it, but gameplay never seems satisfying to me, always leaves me feeling like I just spent an hour arguing with something. I'd be willing to overlook most everything else except that the AI uses that patented "read your button inputs and always respond with the one perfect thing you are mathematically not prepared for" style which is pretty much one of my least favorite things on earth. That ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t becomes a matter of outsmarting/tricking a computer instead of playing the game. Yes, I know, play with humans instead. If you've got friends to play with, sure, but I don't have the mental fortitude these days to put up with randoms.I guess I'll refrain from plugging a specific other franchise this time, but SF has really fallen behind all the other mainstream fighting franchises with this one, while others have hit astonishing new strides. I mean, it does feel like Street Fighter, that's for sure. Like SF2 but slower and clumsier. I don't want to call it bad, but I don't really have fun with it, and that should be what matters here -- I can't personally recommend it to most people.

number of helpful: 19 of 36 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												TL;DR - Very little content, and multiplayer is too hard. Avoid, unless you like salty Spam n' cheese.(Updated for Ultra)1) GFWL  - Support for online play through Games for Windows Live expired July 2014?Update: Online play has been transfered over to Steamworks. Capcom made statements implying that AE (Steam) players would be able to play against Ultra players. However, I have been unable to confirm this. Servers for GfWL are supposedly still active. So, if you did not transfer your game to Steam, have recently purchased AE via Amazon, or still have your old "CD key"... you can still play on GfWL... supposedly. I have not been able to confirm this either.2) Trial / Challenge Mode - A number of factors make this mode impossibly difficult. This mode asks you to perform a specific set of moves/attacks in a sequence. However, there is no explanation and no demonstration. Believe me, it sounds easy to do these sequences, but they are anything but that. The game will ask you to hit your opponent with say, 2 light kicks in a row. You won't be able to do it! It makes no logical sense whatsoever!  - I'm told these are "links". I'm told that with patience and experimentation, you can eventually learn them. I found that you must have perfect timing, spacing and execution. A fraction of a second off, and you fail. The average player will NEVER clear all trials for one(any) character. (Even if you use a guide!) The worst part is that the "dummy" character will block semi-randomly. This means that even if you are good at performing the links, you still risk failure.3) Online Play - The game's matchmaking system is just horrible. It's gotten even worse since the beta patch. The game ranks you in a number of different ways. The game is supposed to use this to find similar opponents. I, for example, have roughly 500 Player Points(PP). When I attempt to find opponents using the "same skill" setting, it gives me players with 3000+ PP. It isn't even remotely close to fair. This, and other factors, make online play is exceedingly difficult.4) It Doesn't Matter How Much Time You Play - The level of competition in this game is too high. My win percentage, after nearly TWO YEARS of serious effort, is around 35%. I've put over 700 hours into this game. (More than shown here, I know. I played on a friend's Xbox before I owned this version. Also, Steam didn't record hours played in offline mode.) I've spent nearly as much time researching in an effort to get better. Nothing has worked-out. Ultimately, I gave up on being good. Improving in the game feels more like work than entertainment. - The sad part is that I'm actually pretty good at the game. It just doesn't matter because my average opponent is still x10 better. I've wasted a lot of time on this game. Don't make the same mistake! Abandon all hope if you play USF4 online.5) Online PLAYERS - The vast majority of people you'll run into online are jerks. There is a lot of trash talk. There is a lot of rage. (Not surprising really.) It is so bad, I had to mute voice chat. The better players will stomp you, and then play around. They won't even fight you. They'll just run away as long as they have the advantage. If you try to give up, most players won't accept it. They'll hit you a few times, and then taunt until time runs out. Alternately, they send a trollish message like, "whats wrong ;D". - The kind of person that plays this game... you don't want to know that kind of person. Here's a quote from "The Fighting Game Primer" which can be found at the popular shoryuken website: "Your job is to take the tools the designers have given you - characters with moves - and turn the game into a sheer mess of broken parts that no one ever wants to play again." This ideal has been widely adopted by online players. It is a very good reason to avoid this game. Being locked into place, unable to move because your opponent's attacks never end? That's not fun. - The Fighting Game Community(FGC) are made up of the most elitist people you will ever encounter. They like to say, "nothing is cheap". Yet these same people complain when someone is "random" or "lame" or "spammy". Their gameplay is highly respectable, yours is lame. See?6) Arcade Mode - The best part of this mode is the arcade experience. By that, I refer to the "Battle Request" feature. This allows online players to challenge you whilst you play Arcade Mode. (Just like at a real arcade!) Aside from that, it's bad news. Even on "medium" CPU opponents can be unbelievably difficult. (Blocking everything and countering/punishing with ultra/super!) - A.I. has improved considerably in Ultra. It now fights much like a typical online warrior. Which means it will cheese you to death. It will find a move you have trouble dealing with, and it will spam it. If you have trouble teching throws, it'll throw you at every opportunity. If there's a specific special move that keeps hitting you, it'll use that move frequently. This is both good AND bad. For one thing, it's really annoying. (It's nice to just fight a dumb A.I. sometimes.) On the other hand, it better prepares players for online play. Anything that can do *that*, is a BIG plus. The A.I. will also block/avoid/punish a lot of things that previously, it would ignore. (Like Ultras. Instead of just eating them. Although it still does that occassionally.) - Seth still too strong. It must be hard to balance a character with all the greatest moves the game has to offer! Still... more than a little ridiculous that everything he does is un-punishable.7) Ultra Combos - Ultra combos are like super moves, only more potent. Ultras are represented by a meter separate from your super meter. The ultra meter is charged as you take damage. The idea is that this gives you a big attack with which to make a comeback. Unfortunately, most characters make it VERY obvious that they are going to utilize their Ultra. As a result, most Ultras are very easy to block or evade entirely. Even worse, your character will just stand there helplessly for several seconds afterward. So, performing your Ultra could lose you the match. - It is possible to make your Ultra part of a bigger combo. However, this almost always requires a difficult timing that demands precise execution. (Which can be ruined by marginal lag.) It's just another tool for the good players to beat you. So much for a comeback!8) Old-School Experts - Many of Street Fighter's biggest fans (and pros) have joined Capcom over the years. As a result, SF4 is "By pros, for pros." If EVO is any indication, they like SF just the way it is. Many pros acknowledge the game is quite difficult to get into, but they have no idea. If you developed your skills back during the days of S-Turbo, then you don't know what it is like to start these days. A lot of what you have learned has become something you just assume, or take for granted. I'm being asked to learn, before I can EVER hope to win, TWENTY-FIVE YEARS worth of tactics and strategies.I gave up on this one. I only play to remind myself why I quit! I can't recommend it to anyone. Even if you have LOADS of free time to sink into the game. After two years of effort, I'm ready to say it's just not possible to get into this genre. You have to have natural talent. You simply CANNOT train to be good at this game.Don't believe me? Have fun losing. Because, if you are not god-like-perfect at fighting games, losing is the only possibility when you play Street Fighter IV online. If you hear that this game is great for casual play, please know this is a lie. This is not a game for casual or even average players. This game is for fighting game PROS ONLY. Anyone else will waste their money and time. (Like me.)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
												Being an old school Street Fighter fan, and I still have and play Super Street Fighter 2 Turbo (SNES), I thought I would give this new Street Fighter a shot. Today I learned that the SNES controller is much better at Street Fighter  games than my Logitech 310. I crouch hitting my left trigger just to watch my fighter looking at the other fighter without doing a sweep or anything. The control on USF4 is horrible (compared to SSF2T on SNES). I play sports games like FIFA and NBA 2k without any trouble but this game seems to not work unless you button smash. v,>,punch does two moves  and never the actual v,>,punch move when you need it. The game also seems to not realize that you missed a flying kick or punch you cant go striaght into a move while still in the air after a miss but I guess logic has no place in this game.Went to my friends house to pick up his arcade control and this game is amazing. You need the arcade style control to play it which is sad because as a young child I use to play with a gamepad and that's the only reason why I got this game. For Street Fighter fans I would say get it on sale. For someone just getting into Street Fighter I would totally tell you to get this game. I will try to get another gamepad to see if it makes the game better but I doubt it.tl;dr game sucks with a gamepad but is awesome with arcade control 8/10

content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												The best fighting game to date. - Huge cast, including classic SF II chars like Guile and Bipson, new chars like Juri and Gouken, even Final Fight chars were added, like Cody and Poison.- The core gameplay is still very similar to SF II, with a more slow game pace focused on zoning, anti-air and short combos.- The new mechanics, like the focus attack and the ultras add more depth to the fight, make the game very technical on a high level.The only problem I can think of is that some game mechanics like the focus cancel were made thinking in an arcade stick, you wont be able to pull it off on a pad or keyboard, so I would say that an arcade stick is recommend to play the game on a high level.I rate it as: 5/5

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2014
												Made by fans for fans.If you are new to the series, then this is a must buy.If you've played the old versions of the game, then you have already bought Ultra.If you're thinking "this is a new version of an old game", then you probably haven't played SF4 ever and you're just an internet troll .The definitive version of the game. There really isn't any competition when it comes to deep, involved fighting mechanics. You aren't drowned in a quandary of different systems and minutia. Everything simply works.The balance is also razor thin. The worst characters (when looking at a 10 point match up tier list) are only 20% below the best. The same can't be said for pretty much any fighting game aside from SF2. Using MVC3 as an example, the best character is actually close to 250% better than the worst (on a match up based tier list).You also don't have to sit there and watch the other person play while your character is endlessly juggled for half the match. Combos are there but they are swift and succinct. No more 15-20 second long combos of MVC3 and King of Fighters 13.The character variety is amazing. The inputs are tight and responsive while also demanding that you learn your character. There is no dial-a-combo system, so mistakes are still risky but not as risky as Street Fighter X Tekken where stray jabs lead to full out dial-a-combos.If you are new to fighting games this is absolutely, positively a 10. If you have the older versions of Street Fighter 4 then this is a 9, seeing as how you've tread this ground before.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												As far as fighters go this is the cornerstone. I feel that no fighter collection would be complete without this one. In my personal opinion I'm not the biggest fan of fighters but this one catches my attention. I've always kinda sucked at fighters but this one was easy to learn because of its great range in characters. Some characters are very simple for beginners and get gradually more complicated as you rise in skill level. That being said there are very few to no characters that i would say are "op" or "cheap" and none of which are unbeatable given your own skill level when facing them. The networking isn't the best as we all know, but I can't say that it's been horrid for me when playing with people in my area or others that share the same connection. I've used almost any controller you can think of from consoles to fight sticks and havent had any issues. Taking everything into account, I would definitely recommend this to anyone who wants to get into fighters.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												This game is good, but it comes with a few conditions:If you have shaky internet, don't expect a good online experience.  It won't even come close to acceptable.Use forced Vsync via your graphics card (NOT IN-GAME VSYNC).  For whatever crazy and nonsensical reason, this game runs better online with it slammed at 60 fps via Vsync and not just because you have the in-game option set to "fixed".  Also, you'll want to mess around with your Vsync options to test for input lag.  For me, I use adaptive Vsync because the game is generally good at staying at a constant framerate on my setup, so this produces the best in both online environments and in terms of input lag for me.  Regular Vsync and triple buffered Vsync cause a noticable delay on my rig.  For others it is different and it really just depends, but using Vsync in some manner should be aimed for.The game is standard SFIV fair: easy to understand, hard to master.  This game is both deceptively accessible and not accessible.  Be warned, you will have the urge to practice.  And if you don't, well time to move on I guess.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												I am a beginner in SF4 but have quite a few hours of SF2HDR under my belt. So far the things that make this game are the matchmaking, training modes and that there are quite a lot of people playing online.Any online competitive game that has a decent ranking matchmaking system that is customisable for skill and ping is immediately going to get people playing. And SF4 does it very well. The only complaint I have is that there isn't more of an emphasis on a skill-per-character rank. It is already implemented in SF4, but it seems to rank mostly on the global points rather than the points for a particular character. Over all though, this is nearly as good as Star Craft 2. And in someways, actually better.Being able to be waiting for an online game while being in the single player game is awesome too!The downsides are mostly related to my gameplay tastes. I love games that are easy to play and hard to master. SF2HDR is pretty good for this. Unfortunately, SF4 brings back an execution barrier to entry which I don't enjoy. I much prefer the decision making based on spacing, zoning, yomi, etc rather than mostly to do with if I can actually carry out a set of moves.So what would I give USF4? A big thumbs up for online play and fun and a big thumbs down for lacking the courage to do things differently from historical fighting games and remove the emphasis on combos.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												Pros:- Large pool of characters to choose from- Variety of playstyles- Healthy amount of players online for a fighting game on steam- Good game to get into for people looking into the genre- Deep meta game you can research online- Decent community activity (tournaments, youtube videos, streams, etc.)- Constantly updated in regards to balancingCons:- Dodgy netcode issues resulting in some laggy matches depending on your location- Lacking in features that other fighting games have- Barebones single-player- Hard to communicate with other players without a mic- Much more players on consoles than PCConclusion: Definitely recommend if you don't already own it on Xbox/PS3. Wish they would patch the netcode issues though. I recommend you invest in a fightstick or at least a controller to play however. Fighting games played on a keyboard sucks.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												The 5th iteration of Street Fighter 4 on PC, and somehow the game has taken gigantic steps backwards.The game itself, not just the netcode, still needs a major patch and at this point, I don't think we'll ever get it. For example, sometimes the MENUS lag. Yeah. Widespread frame rate and other assorted graphical issues for almost all users from the get-go, with no clear, definitive way to fix them. There are so many guides and posts for tweaks and workarounds that users can utilize on their end to make the game playable, but there are also so many issues that it becomes pretty confusing. Some fixes work for some users and have no effect for others. Whatever the Steam transition and the release of Ultra did to this game really broke it. The netcode is infamously terrible and has been covered to death. It has improved but still bad overall. Do I recommend this game? Yes and no. Yes, if you are willing to tinker with the game and your system to get it running right. USF4 can be a lot of fun. With that said, there are issues you WILL need to address if you decide to play, and there are still many issues with the online play. So keep those things in mind before you buy.I don't know if Capcom will get this game fixed. Despite the beta and patch, many problems remain.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												I'm no hardcore competitive type, so I can't speak to how that works. But I can tell you, I've enjoyed this game, both on this and the PS3 where I usually play it. Lots of people complain about lag, but that's less true than it was a few months ago. This is slow paced, and if you're like me, used to games like BlazBlu, Guilty Gear, etc, you're going to be thrown by the weird♥♥♥♥♥pacing, as the matches look less ilke dances far more like mind games. THat's not so much a knock on it, as it is a taste thing. As much fun as I have with this, it isn't my taste. But it would be unfair of me to say no to it purely on the grounds it's not my preferred type, that'd be like giving a Chinese restaurant a bad review for not serving pizzas. What I can hold against it is its aesthetic. This game is ugly as a Brock Lesnar suplex. Some visual options make some slight increase in aesthetic, but not too much. I don't know what they were going for, but they missed. Bad.As far as Street Fighter's go, it's, well, clearly a late game in the series. If you aren't a Street Fighter (or other fighting game fan) go back and futz around in the earlier games a while. It'll do you some good. Hell, if you are another game fan, at least give it a shot. That's the basis that later gaems like this are based off. This game has a lot of systems to remember. I might actually say too many. Street FIghter's greatest advantage is its simplicity, and this feels more like something someone else should be making at times. For all those criticisms, it's still good. It's a well-made fighting game. The iconic cast is present, and brings in some new friends as well. It could afford to be simpler, and prettier, but for what it is, you're getting your money's worth. If you're not sure if you'd like the game, give it a try.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2016
												I've played every iteration and patch of this game, minus the original arcade release (and even the beta Ultra release while in Japan), and would say this is my favorite iteration thus far. The balance is as good as it has ever been, while supporting many different playstyles. This version is a love letter to fans of SF4. Tons of content (arcade mode, trials, robust training mode) for those who shy away from playing online or with a friend, or even competitively.Having said that, some fighting game fans have a hard time enjoying this one. I would be willing to be this is in regard to mid to high level competitive play. Casual fans of fighting games will find a lot to enjoy. The other issue, as of writing this, is that the online scene has all but faded away. Ranked matches will be your only way of finding competition unless you already know a group of active online players. The player base has moved on to SF5, I suspect.Regardless of what the online scene looks like, this is one of the most solid entries in the series.  Super Turbo and 3rd Strike players would hate me for saying this, but I honestly think Ultra belongs on the same pedestal.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												I am a beginner in SF4 but have quite a few hours of SF2HDR under my belt. So far the things that make this game are the matchmaking, training modes and that there are quite a lot of people playing online.Any online competitive game that has a decent ranking matchmaking system that is customisable for skill and ping is immediately going to get people playing. And SF4 does it very well. The only complaint I have is that there isn't more of an emphasis on a skill-per-character rank. It is already implemented in SF4, but it seems to rank mostly on the global points rather than the points for a particular character. Over all though, this is nearly as good as Star Craft 2. And in someways, actually better.Being able to be waiting for an online game while being in the single player game is awesome too!The downsides are mostly related to my gameplay tastes. I love games that are easy to play and hard to master. SF2HDR is pretty good for this. Unfortunately, SF4 brings back an execution barrier to entry which I don't enjoy. I much prefer the decision making based on spacing, zoning, yomi, etc rather than mostly to do with if I can actually carry out a set of moves.So what would I give USF4? A big thumbs up for online play and fun and a big thumbs down for lacking the courage to do things differently from historical fighting games and remove the emphasis on combos.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												[Opening]I'm going to have to revoke my previous review for this game because I just realized I've played every Street Fighter game 'cep' 1 and Alpha 1, including the Street Fighter V beta.  And, in hindsight, I've discovered just how terrible the controls are in this game.I grew up in the arcades back in the day, playing Samurai Shodown, Street Fighter II Champion Edition, World Heroes and whatever else I could stick my quarters into.  I've always known fighting games to have tight controls, and while I haven't always played them competitively (as much as I would've loved to), this game does not have tight controls.  Lemme tell you what you can expect to see a lot of in this game.[The Cons]First off is negative edge.  Negative edge is present in all fighting games.  When you press a normal attack button, then cancel it into a special move, occasionally fighting games will take the previous button press and apply it to your next movement.  This usually happens if you take too long to release the first button you press in this sequence.  In Street Fighter IV, you can expect to see this happen a lot.The next one is something I honestly don't know if there's a name for yet.  People who play this game will burn meter if for no other reason than to prevent the use of a super move.  They do this because sometimes, when you do a special move with a similar motion to your character's super move, the game will automatically cancel your previous special move into a super move, even if you only pushed the button once.One frame links (and two frame links, etc.).  Just one frame links.  This is the only fighting game that has them.  For the uninitiated, a one frame link is when you press one normal attack button, then press another one at ONE VERY SPECIFIC frame of animation from the previous attack.  One frame at sixty frames a second.  Doing this is insanely difficult, ESPECIALLY ONLINE, and takes more patience and practice than anything I've ever had to do and I've been playing fighting games for over twenty years.  I just keep my combos simple.The input leniancy.  This is the game's worst offender.  You will get misinputs for days on account of how the game "guesses" when you do any complex motion.  It even lead to a glitch (or "feature") called priority linking, or plinking, in which you press two buttons of the same type.  Say you want a medium kick to come out at the speed of a light kick.  What you do is press both buttons and the game will always give you the attack of the stronger button, but it gives it the priority of the lesser button pressed.  This makes combos easier, but this input leniancy applies to every button pressed.  When the game handles directional inputs...honestly, I don't know.  I haven't really figured out how it handles those at all.  There's been too many times I just don't know how I got the input I got.And before any of you scrubs who never played a Street Fighter game before come running to defend it saying "You just can't do these moves/combos 'cuz you suck," remember.  I've been playing fighting games for over 20 years.  I've put way more practice into Street Fighter as a franchise than any of you.  That being said, however, I'll list some pros, now that I've got all the cons out of the way.[The Pros]It's got a great cast of characters from all the Street Fighter games and some new ones.It looks great.The PC version has easily the best netcode.  You'll still get some lag (and laggers), but netcode doesn't fix people's bad connections, it just makes the game flow a little better.  And it does flow well.  When it wants to.Being the most popular fighting game currently on the market, you'll never have trouble finding people to fight.  Online is always crowded, no matter which platform you play it on.  It saddens me that I can't blame the netcode for some of the BS that happens in this game.Ranked mode's scoring and ranking is based off the same as professional chess tournaments.  You get points when you beat somebody, lose 'em when you lose and those points determine your rank.  PP (Player Points) applies to your rank as a player and BP (Battle Points) refers to your rank with your current character.[Closing]Play 3rd Strike on home consoles or wait for Street Fighter V.  If you haven't played this game yet, you're not missing anything.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												I would reccomend this game to anyone for 2 reasons. One is a more opinionated reason because I feel like this game takes  actual skill for playing the game and skill for learning how to correctly input commands (Like quarter circle back then punch or 270 degree foward circle then kick); if you cannot do that or know that you mess up inputs constantly, you are basically shooting your own foot. The second reason is the online - at this moment in time that I write this very short review about the game - is amazing since the game moved from GFWL to Steamworks; you are basically only left with playing with friends from the same country and single player modes which is great!My opinion this game is worth it if you are looking for a more multiplayer, boost your own skills game at it's current online state. But if you wanna mess with friends or mess offline then it is okay if it goes on sale.I believe people will have less fun playing a game like Tekken, seeing as skill is required less on the game itself and not just learning how to flawlessly input commands which every character shares and has to follow (except for charge characters).But yes, that is my opinion, and long term Street Fighter fans will find this a load of sense, but if you are a diehard Street Fighter fan; why are you reading this in the first place?(maybe because you are so awesome)?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												SF4 is easily the best fighting game to come out in the past... I dunno, 10 years.  This is the game you basically need to play if you're into fighting games at all, imo.  It's a bit slower paced, yes.  But the roster is huge and varied, there's a character here for just about everyone's style.  The presentation can't be topped, I can't overemphasize how HYPE that♥♥♥♥♥♥gets.  SF4's neutral game is mostly about footsies and space control, in a really intense and understated way that not a lot of other fighting games can touch.  It's all about fundamentals, here.  You can learn your combos, sure.  You can spend time in training mode; absolutely, you should.  But the mindgames in SF4 are so crazy.  You don't have to be an input master to do well.It also just so happens to be incredibly well balanced, especially considering how many characters there are.  It's got a pretty damn good online system, and you can watch other people's replays.  What more could you ask for?As of the release of Ultra, there's quite a few new characters to screw around with, including some SF3 characters.  Most of them are pretty cool I guess?  None of them can replace my main, though.  NOW, FACE THE MIGHTY BISON.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												I am a beginner in SF4 but have quite a few hours of SF2HDR under my belt. So far the things that make this game are the matchmaking, training modes and that there are quite a lot of people playing online.Any online competitive game that has a decent ranking matchmaking system that is customisable for skill and ping is immediately going to get people playing. And SF4 does it very well. The only complaint I have is that there isn't more of an emphasis on a skill-per-character rank. It is already implemented in SF4, but it seems to rank mostly on the global points rather than the points for a particular character. Over all though, this is nearly as good as Star Craft 2. And in someways, actually better.Being able to be waiting for an online game while being in the single player game is awesome too!The downsides are mostly related to my gameplay tastes. I love games that are easy to play and hard to master. SF2HDR is pretty good for this. Unfortunately, SF4 brings back an execution barrier to entry which I don't enjoy. I much prefer the decision making based on spacing, zoning, yomi, etc rather than mostly to do with if I can actually carry out a set of moves.So what would I give USF4? A big thumbs up for online play and fun and a big thumbs down for lacking the courage to do things differently from historical fighting games and remove the emphasis on combos.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												One of the best if not the best 2d fighting game out there - easy to learn - hard to master. There are 30+ characters in game and almost all of them are very different. It is rely hard to be good at multiple characters, it takes some time to master one character. I have around 500h hours in this game and can play only 1 character at a decent level.Combos are done by 1 - 2 frame links, you need to spend some time in a training room if you want to get a hang of them. The best thing about them, is that in "trials" there are only few combos, all other combos you have to figure out by yourself or just look them up on youtube.There are multiple gameplay styles posibilities with same character. You can be super agresive, or rely passive or just find your own thing. You can play at prety decent level without complicated combos, but you will have to outsmart your oponent more times then.This game is all about multiplayer it runs very smoothly, without lags. Single player is ladder type gameplay with a boss at the end. There a 24 trials for each character that are rely hard, you have to feel the character well in order to complete them.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2016
												I've played every iteration and patch of this game, minus the original arcade release (and even the beta Ultra release while in Japan), and would say this is my favorite iteration thus far. The balance is as good as it has ever been, while supporting many different playstyles. This version is a love letter to fans of SF4. Tons of content (arcade mode, trials, robust training mode) for those who shy away from playing online or with a friend, or even competitively.Having said that, some fighting game fans have a hard time enjoying this one. I would be willing to be this is in regard to mid to high level competitive play. Casual fans of fighting games will find a lot to enjoy. The other issue, as of writing this, is that the online scene has all but faded away. Ranked matches will be your only way of finding competition unless you already know a group of active online players. The player base has moved on to SF5, I suspect.Regardless of what the online scene looks like, this is one of the most solid entries in the series.  Super Turbo and 3rd Strike players would hate me for saying this, but I honestly think Ultra belongs on the same pedestal.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												I'm no hardcore competitive type, so I can't speak to how that works. But I can tell you, I've enjoyed this game, both on this and the PS3 where I usually play it. Lots of people complain about lag, but that's less true than it was a few months ago. This is slow paced, and if you're like me, used to games like BlazBlu, Guilty Gear, etc, you're going to be thrown by the weird♥♥♥♥♥pacing, as the matches look less ilke dances far more like mind games. THat's not so much a knock on it, as it is a taste thing. As much fun as I have with this, it isn't my taste. But it would be unfair of me to say no to it purely on the grounds it's not my preferred type, that'd be like giving a Chinese restaurant a bad review for not serving pizzas. What I can hold against it is its aesthetic. This game is ugly as a Brock Lesnar suplex. Some visual options make some slight increase in aesthetic, but not too much. I don't know what they were going for, but they missed. Bad.As far as Street Fighter's go, it's, well, clearly a late game in the series. If you aren't a Street Fighter (or other fighting game fan) go back and futz around in the earlier games a while. It'll do you some good. Hell, if you are another game fan, at least give it a shot. That's the basis that later gaems like this are based off. This game has a lot of systems to remember. I might actually say too many. Street FIghter's greatest advantage is its simplicity, and this feels more like something someone else should be making at times. For all those criticisms, it's still good. It's a well-made fighting game. The iconic cast is present, and brings in some new friends as well. It could afford to be simpler, and prettier, but for what it is, you're getting your money's worth. If you're not sure if you'd like the game, give it a try.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												an excellent game to introduce you to the genre, although the absolute best in-game tutorial for fighting games would be in skullgirls. this game does not have an in-game tutorial and many concepts are left for you to figure out on your own. i can't think of anything in the current state of the game that a casual player would immediately be able to identify as cheap or spammable. you must exercise fundamentals to get anywhere in this game and those skills (zoning, footsies, neutral, decision making, positioning, match-up recognition, frame data) can easily translate to other games in the genre, or all games if you're a huge nerd like me! i highly recommend learning the game with a buddy since the online player base is highly experienced and, even though you can learn from losses, you will get much more from playing with someone on a similar skill level. shoryuken.com , youtube tutorials, and watching streams of the game on twitch.tv are good ways to learn, but nothing beats playing a friend.settings wise, it is a MUST that you turn OFF vsync (having it on will introduce input lag, although i heard it is not bad if you implement it on a driver level) and set frame rate to FIXED (allows the game to always run the game at 60fps, even if that means skipping frames [essential for gameplay since it keeps timings consistent and is as the game was intended to be played]. setting this to variable or smooth will allow the game to run under 60fps and this is bad due to multiple gameplay and netcode reasons.)

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												I would reccomend this game to anyone for 2 reasons. One is a more opinionated reason because I feel like this game takes  actual skill for playing the game and skill for learning how to correctly input commands (Like quarter circle back then punch or 270 degree foward circle then kick); if you cannot do that or know that you mess up inputs constantly, you are basically shooting your own foot. The second reason is the online - at this moment in time that I write this very short review about the game - is amazing since the game moved from GFWL to Steamworks; you are basically only left with playing with friends from the same country and single player modes which is great!My opinion this game is worth it if you are looking for a more multiplayer, boost your own skills game at it's current online state. But if you wanna mess with friends or mess offline then it is okay if it goes on sale.I believe people will have less fun playing a game like Tekken, seeing as skill is required less on the game itself and not just learning how to flawlessly input commands which every character shares and has to follow (except for charge characters).But yes, that is my opinion, and long term Street Fighter fans will find this a load of sense, but if you are a diehard Street Fighter fan; why are you reading this in the first place?(maybe because you are so awesome)?

content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												I got alot of enjoyment out of the SF IV series over the years, and I feel t-hat this is the most definitive version yet- plenty of characters to choose from, lots of different modes to play, and many more! I really have no gripes with this game other than the frustration brought forth from trial mode and some of the design choices for the alternate costumes-neither which will hamper your gameplay experience. I throughly recommend this game to longtime fans of SF and newbies alike!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												This has been the best Street Fighter thus far IMO. I feel that this game requires more skill and thought processing than V. IV allowed players to be creative with their characters and the mechanics such as FADC, FA, and being able to link light attacks into Heavy attacks or medium attacks (and vice versa) gave this game life. I am aware that some attacks are like this in V, but not as much and a lot of combos start off with either st.mp or cr.mp to get everything going. I feel that V lacks the fidelity and still has a lot that needs to be worked on. Yes, IV had its problems (it still does), but guess what, V carries out some of those problems as well. But, everyone has their own opinions about both these games. I hope this review helps (or somewhat does) gamers who are trying to look for a good competitive and serious game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												I would reccomend this game to anyone for 2 reasons. One is a more opinionated reason because I feel like this game takes  actual skill for playing the game and skill for learning how to correctly input commands (Like quarter circle back then punch or 270 degree foward circle then kick); if you cannot do that or know that you mess up inputs constantly, you are basically shooting your own foot. The second reason is the online - at this moment in time that I write this very short review about the game - is amazing since the game moved from GFWL to Steamworks; you are basically only left with playing with friends from the same country and single player modes which is great!My opinion this game is worth it if you are looking for a more multiplayer, boost your own skills game at it's current online state. But if you wanna mess with friends or mess offline then it is okay if it goes on sale.I believe people will have less fun playing a game like Tekken, seeing as skill is required less on the game itself and not just learning how to flawlessly input commands which every character shares and has to follow (except for charge characters).But yes, that is my opinion, and long term Street Fighter fans will find this a load of sense, but if you are a diehard Street Fighter fan; why are you reading this in the first place?(maybe because you are so awesome)?

Wish SF5 took some pointers from this game but sadly they seem to go in a different direction4/5 would get a clean 5 if the netcode was better, it wasnt a straight up port, and character balance was better!

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												Love this game, have played Street Fighter in arcades and at the local dairies and fish 'n' chip shops since I was a kid. SSFIV:AE is a very different game to those first few titles but it still evokes the same sense of awe when I play. Ultra SFIV is almost upon us and I am looking forward to the changes and the addition of a few new faces. With all that said though, this game is BRUTAL to get in to as a beginner, even all the years I have played casually never really prepared me for the depth and technical possibilities of the SFIV series. That coupled with the absolutely average connections I get to most people (even in the same area, don't even mention overseas) can mean weeks of losses and probably the most frustration I have ever exprienced in a fighting game. But still, the payoff is there - you practice, you WILL get better. I almost liken this kind of game to the guitar, hours of practice is required to train your muscles to do the things in your head without actually thinking about the inputs. Actually, ♥♥♥♥ this game - it drives me nuts. Haha.
