number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												 It's Street Fighter 2 +2 then Ultra'd. I love SFII and most of the 90s SF games. I have some resentment towards Capcom millking this series so much. People that complain about paying for DLC that should be included day one  don't remember or weren't alive for what Capcom did the the SNES/Genesis from 1992-94. Every year 4 more characters and another 70-75 bucks.  Why would we pay that. Well it made the fighting genre popular and was the best one.(don't get me wronge SNK put some  good compition) There wasn't much else either at the time. So here we are on the 4th one.   I like this here SF4 a lot. A lot more than SF3. Really it would be between this and SSF2 or Alpha 3 as the best in the series. The game play brings me back 24 years when I first tried Street Fighter 2. Everything came back to me and I got right back to what I did so well in arcades 20 something years ago. Won matches again and again. This game works so well I really don't see a need for a 5th. I mean this one didn't do much gameplay wise to the old formula. It's an update, and a good one at that.  My only issue with this game is the stages are random and don't go with characters. There are also fewer stages to characters as well. Some may say that doesn't matter, but it does. That was part of the fun to get to a characters stage. It said something about the character.  Everything else though is awesome. From the characters, to the graphics, to the controls. Everything is good, If you were a fan of the SF at all get this!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												Ultimate Street Fighter 4: Super DLC Edition PROS-Plenty of character variety-Lots of Modes & UnlockablesCONS-NOT for Casuals-Online Mode(s) are Laggy, Inconsistant & has cheaters-Huge difficulty curve-Sore Thumbs & Fingers-Best Played with an Arcade Controller-No Tutorial-DLC (Disk Locked Content) is Overpriced -Technical IssuesNegativesRemember when you could unlock costumes & characters by simply playing the game?  Well now you have to spend more money cause ♥♥♥♥ YOU that's why!Even though the DLC upsets me greatly & buying 3 versions of the same game also upsets me (SF4, SF4:AE, USF4)  it's still a great game & worthy of your time.  The DLC is a god awful overpriced cash grab. You might as well just wait for a sale & get all the DLC cheap.  That's what I did.  They don't add anything except costumes anyways.  Some DLC are locked as preorder bonuses & you can't get them anymore which is also just a terrible business practice that I hate very much.DLC whining aside, the game itself is good excluding the online modes.  The ranked system leaves much to be desired.  Here's how most of my games end up matched when in ranked.  Either the game puts me against an A+ rank (I'm a D rank) & I get destroyed in 10 seconds, the game puts me up against someone who either abuses some kind of lag exploit by downloading in the background or just has a crap ISP & the game is played at 5FPS, or I get put against someone who plays like an infant & I win easily.  Also, there are a ton of fireball spammers (which isn't the games fault but still is an annoyance).  Online ranked is also full of macro users.  What this means is they mod a controller to input specific commands when they just press a single button.  So, sometimes you will find players who are low ranked & somehow always manage to input pitch perfect combos that you'd only see a high ranking player be able to pull off.  AKA, Cheaters.Also, this game makes my thumbs & fingers hurt.  Like, a lot.  After about an hour or so of playing trying to beat Arcade on Hardest or just playing online trying to rank up my hands will cramp & I can't continue to play anymore afterwards.  Seriously, if you make a game that causes people pain from playing it you've done something wrong. Features The real draw here is the local multiplayer & arcade modes since there's no lag & you can set your own rules.  The most annoying part is that this game is designed with an Arcade Stick in mind.  So, unless you're planning on playing this with an expensive & sturdy arcade controller don't bother playing it seriously.  Your thumbs will thank you for this.The game also doesn't have a tutorial which is a darn shame.  There is a challenge mode which shows you some basics but "some" is the key word here.  It barely shows you how to do anything with zero explanation.  I have plenty of 2D fighting games at my disposal & nearly all of them have some kind of tutorial mode, so why can't a AAA game developer like Capcom hash out some extra funding to make one?  A game like this should have an in-depth tutorial for every indivitual character.  Instead you get a half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥challenge mode that any average player will find impossible to complete 100%. Technical Issues The game also has issues.  A good example is turning on V-Sync or Anti-Aliasing will cause an input lag effect.  This means there will be a delay on when you press a button to when your character does what you commanded.  If you have both on the effect is very noticable.  You'll have to turn these both off if you want a decent gameplay experience.  Another problem I have frequently is when trying to throw a fireball the character will instead throw an uppercut.  This happens on several occasions & is very frequent.  That's what happens when you make a game that uses such similar button presses to seperate different moves.  This is another problem that seems the only way to fix is to go out & buy an arcade controller or some kind of controller that's better suited for fighting games, which I'm not going to do.  There are also some odd hitboxes, best example of this is Hugo.  He's the biggest character in the game, slow & lumbering grappler, but his hitbox is the same size as Ken's or Cammy's.  Some moves will just go straight through his head while he's ducking.  Not blocking, just ducking.  One of the dumbest things I've ever seen in any game ever.Combos require too much precision to pull off properly.  You also can't make your own combos in this game.  You have to figure out what combos the game will let you pull off for each character or look them up in a guide.  Also, there are a lot of tricks & such that the game itself will not tell you anything about so a guide is pretty much mandatory to be good at this game.  The biggest tactic being the dash cancel the game tells you nothing about. Overall Overall, the game itself is good but much of which is meant specifically for E-Sports & serious players only.  Casuals should probably steer clear of online modes otherwise (if you're like me) you'll just get frustrated at how poorly the game controls with a standard controller & how the online modes are just utter garbage that are full of lag spikes & people who take the game way too seriously.In short, Go Pro or Go Home.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 16, 2015
												It's the first Street Fighter game I have played, and after saying that I didn't like traditional fighting games (besides dbz) for years, I actually quite like it. "World's Greatest Fighting Game" is a bit of a big stretch, I mean it's not smash melee, the actual best fighting game.Pros:+Cartoon style graphics (age well)+Online+Customisable character colours, taunts, actions+Multiple modes+Plenty of stages+Good price+Good character roster+Great cutscenes (anime and sketch style intro)+Sound design+Tutorial for moves and some basic combos (Trials/Ultra Trials)+Icons and EmblemsCons:-Doesn't teach you how to do everything you need-Some clone characters-Ranking system puts you with people much better (Only won 1/100 matches and only 5 of those people were even close to my ranking)Final Verdict:I am very impressed by this, though it's my first street fighter I'll probably try other street fighters and maybe even some other fighting games. It's not the best fighting game like it makes it out to be, but as a traditional fighting game it seems like it is up there near the top. It has the problems that all traditional fighting games do, but hey, not all fighting games can be as good8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												As Street Fighter V inches ever so closer, I think it's time to take a look back on the lifespan of one of the more well-known entries in the series. Initally released in 2008, Street Fighter IV has seen so many subsequent updates and rereleases, some of which admittedly feel a bit unnecessary. Nonetheless, all of these versions have ensured the core game's place in the fighting game scene, It had its ups and downs, but Street Fighter IV is still a very robust and shining example of practically everything the series has to offer.PROS-Characters from all sorts of games (The original, II, Alpha, III, and a few new ones)-The biggest roster of a Street Fighter game I know-Several alternate costumes on top of that-Easy-to-play, hard-to-master control scheme-Version select (only available in local versus(sorry, Omega mode))-Evil Ryu is waaaaaay better than regular RyuOf, course, it's not without its flaws:CONS-Character imbalance still sneaks through every once in a while-Alternate costumes are paid DLC in spearate bundles organized by character archetytpes-Arcade-Last-Boss Seth is still a cheating ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥-Lag can pose a greater threat than your opponent, depending on the connection-Decapre (Would this be considered petty?)Even with these flaws, Ultra Street Fighter IV is still the definitive version of the game(even if Seth Killian said that about Arcade Edition), and PC users can mod even more costumes in the game (can you say Spider-Man Fei-Long?). So, in short, I'd still recommend it. It could certainly make the time go by a little faster while waiting for Street Fighter V.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
												Pros- The game is a modern fighting game classic at this point in time The roster is huge. No way you won't like at least one character in this gameStages are prettyMost of the cast are viable in high level play, although some do way better than others. Game is based around footsies and spacing rather than memorizing extremely long combos (for most of the cast)Motions are simplified for new combos (Can also be considered a con)The netcode is pretty solid This game is mod friendly! Best part about it in my opinion. Music is great Cons- DLC costumes are disappointingThe game still looks decent but is graphically a little behind compared to whats to come in the future for games like SFVThe motions for moves are simplified, which seems like its pandering to noobies who probably won't get good anyways Ranked matches are not 2 out of 3's, and you can adjust the amount of rounds and the timer you want, which seems sillyMost of the cast is viable but a lot of the worst characters were already bad in previous versions (IE, Dee Jay)Overall, I think Ultra SF4 is amazing. The PC version is honestly the best version of this game and the game still holds up as one of the best fighting games to come out in recent history. It may seem pretty simple for some newer players who have experience in fighting games, but it's extremely deep. The modding community for this game is outstanding as well. 9 out of 10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												I don't think this game needs any introducing, but I'm going to do this anyway:Ultra Street Fighter IV is the newest in the series of 2D fighting games developed by Capcom, and this series is said to be one of those that coded the genre. I had some experience with Street Fighter II, so I can compare this to some of the older games.First of all: despite the game having cell-shaded 3D graphics, it still sticks to the traditional 2D formula. You might call the graphics not incredible, but they're good enough that you can marvel at all the work in the background or character animations.The gameplay is simple yet fun. All the characters have standard punches and kicks (in the light, medium and heavy varieties), as well as crouching and jumping versions of those. They can block, throw special attacks, use Supers or EX attacks if they get the Super bar high enough, or use Ultras which are fueled by the Revenge gauge that goes up by taking damage, making this a Comeback Mechanic. There are also throws, sped up / delayed wake-ups, Focus Attacks which block damage and guard break, and the new Red Focus Attack which is considered an EX attack (burns Super bar) but can soak up multiple hits (standard Focus Attack can stop only one). This adds to the options for combat and makes for a nice guessing game. Also, this game not being very combo-oriented as other ones (such as Guilty Gear or BlazBlue), it's well-suited for general casual play, as well as high-level play where players can pull off longer combos.As of Ultra, the game has a gigantic roster of 44 fighters available to suit your playstyle, whether you like grappling characters with command grabs, mixup characters, or just want to stick to the standard Shoto Clone (Ryu, Ken etc.). Even the boss characters are more balanced towards general play, which is quite interesting.On the music side, the tunes you hear in the game mostly aren't incredibly memorable, but they're catchy enough that you won't really get tired of listening to them over and over.Overall, this game is a very solid title. Interesting and wide assortment of combat options, a lot of characters to choose from, and fantastic presentation, this game is great for both casuals and tourney-goers.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22
												I've been playing Street Fighter for as long as I can remember.  My earliest memory is of one of my uncles and my older brother scrubbing it up as Sagat and Dictator in SF2 Turbo for the SNES.  I've never really been an arcade rat, but I've played Street Fighter on console pretty consistently my entire life.  Being one of the few kids who got a Sega Saturn helped out with that.  Alpha 2 on Saturn is godlike.  Fighting games were godlike.  That is until 2003 or so and Capcom♥♥♥♥♥♥the bed and started putting out dumb ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t like the Harvey Birdman game and those remedial light gun editions of Resident Evil.  They were going to put out this game called Capcom Fighting Allstars, but I guess somebody was afraid of making too much money and they pussied out.   Maybe nobody over there thought fighting games were popular anymore.  I don't know.  Didn't stop them from putting out that Sengoku Basara fighting game in Japan.  Meanwhile, most of us here in the states didn't really know about King of Fighters or Guilty Gear and were relegated to playing Tekken and the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ 3D Mortal Kombats for a while.  That's alright, though, because in 2008 Street Fighter 4 came out to ignite new hope and excitement for what was becoming a niche genre.  It's too bad Capcom didn't ditch their old habit of releasing multiple versions of the same game by the time it came out.   I understand that they do it because that's the way arcade machines work.  I also understand that reactive balancing can severely frustrate the pro community.  Still, for your average Sally Lunchpail, this kind of♥♥♥♥♥♥puts a serious strain on the wallet.   If you count Arcade Edition 2012, Ultra is the fourth iteration, and the bonuses it adds are basically just flipped assets from X Tekken and a pallette swap of Cammy.  But later on, they added a mode where the characters have weird moves, so I guess everything's cool.  At least it's not like Ultra Street Fighter 2, where they're taking a defibrilator to that dead horse by just adding more shotos.I digress.  If you happen to like Street Fighter 2, you'll probably like Street Fighter 4.  It's got all the same stuff, including all of the characters and then some.  Where the older games introduced totally different casts with each roster,  Street Fighter 4 is more like the greatest hits album of fighting games.  Now with bonus tracks that no one really cares about, like Hakan and Rufus.Also, if you're a masochist, you'll probably enjoy playing this game online.  I have like 35 hours on the steam version of Ultra, but I've been playing Street Fighter IV since vanilla on console.  I've no doubt logged hundreds of hours, if not thousands.  I no lifed Arcade Edition for a while.  That's the kind of thing you do when you work a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ dead end job because the only academic field you're interested in is literature, and there's no real point going to college for it.  So yeah, I'd spend hours in training mode, trying to get better.  Jonesing for a win.  Even if you're a loser in life, you can be a winner in Street Fighter.  Except for me apparently.  Maybe I can't get my brain and my thumbs won't cooperate.  Maybe my background in literature left me too dumb not to fall for stupid ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t tactics.  Whatever it is, I can't seem to get a win most nights.  If you're new to the game, you won't either.  Most of the time, when you do manage to get the upper hand, the scrubby ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you're walloping will most often rage quit at the last minute to rob you of any progress.  That's why you have to be a masochist.  But don't go away thinking of this as a negative review.  Street Fighter 4 is a comfortable game to play, after a while.  You get used to the rhythm of matches.  The familiar characters insure that even a complete beginner will have someone simple enough to play.  (Unless your entire fighting game background is in Smash Brothers or something.  Then, you're pretty much ♥♥♥♥ed.)  Some of the remixes of the music is pretty good.  Juri's theme is pretty good.  Poison is a pretty killer addition to the roster, and a lot of fun to play.  There are tons of modded skins out there if you're into that kind of thing.  Online, much like working a crappy fast food job for minimum wage, you won't make much progress for a long time, but at least you've rolled out of bed and done something.  TL;DR 9/10  Definite must play for fighting game fans.

I don't know what happened with Ultra, but it's just no good for single player.

This problem isn't in the Blazblue, KoF, Samurai Shodown, Darkstalkers, Rival Schools, or other high profile series I've tried... In fact, it's not even in the original Street Fighter IV. I don't know what happened with Ultra, but it's just no good for single player.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												My daughter and I have been on a fighting game kick lately.  I recently was diagnoised with MS and over the past few months gaming and life in general has gotten harder for me due to a number of issues, one of which is lose of motor control in my right hand.  I decide to help battle this by doing my own physical therapy via gaming.  Granted it is rather humbling that my 10 year old daughter is slaughtering me in fighting games, but none the less we are having fun.  Okay this is my lead in for this and a couple other fighting games I am reviewing tonight mostly to just set the some background.Right now there are three fighters we are playing Injustice, Skullgirls and Ultra Street Fighter IV.  Each of these three have their pros and cons.  Injustice has DC characters we enjoy.  Skullgirls has unique tag teams and artwork.  USFIV has a huge list of playable characters and is very well balanced.  My daughter thrashes me bad in the game.  Yes I am man enough to admit it.  That said we are still having a good time.  I picked up the game while on sale however and can't say that for the normal price that we would like it better than Injustice or Skullgirls.  Mainly because it is a complex game and the skill level is high.  I can't speak at all to online or against AI as I have only played against her.  All in all though we have enjoyed the game.  My daughter LOVES playing as Rose.  One question, OMG what is with the women and their huge thighs?  lol.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												Having played both SF IV (ps3) and USF IV (PC)  this update really delivers some much-needed upgrades to the original. There is a healthy variety of characters to suit playstyles and the movesets are the same as previous editions of the franchise. Definitely play this one with some kind of joystick instead of a Dpad or keys. Compared to when I played the original with a PS3 controller, the xbox is much more ergonomically sound. It's a solid game offline (haven't played online) and the combo timing is more forgiving  than other titles I've played in the genre. I'd say its major downside is that it feels old, because like most games that come from Capcom, this one doesn't rock the boat much. It's a great title for fans of the genre, but it probably won't win over any new faces. 7.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												So I have barely played any Ultra Street Fighter IV ever.... Well on Steam it looks that way, but I had it for Windows Live which is why my achievement list looks odd as it says I got the clear 10 trials and clear all trials with one character at the same time. I also main the game on Playstation 4 now and already had it on PS3 and Xbox 360. So I have a little experience with this game before hand.With that said I have noticed some odd things about this particular version. Like hitting an opponent with an anti-air and then getting hit by said opponent from the ground in the very next frame. All of the other frames disappeared. I have it set to run at a fixed rate as my computer can run the game way faster than necessary. So that should not have happened, but it did. The other thing I noticed is the game sometimes has button lag in this version, but not always. It is very inconsistent about that. So that is also kind of interesting to note.Other than those issues this game is fantastic. Despite how some people complain and say, "Well I am still waiting for the Ultra Street Fighter IV Hyper Rainbow Edition", these add-ons were actually heavily demanded by the hardcore fanbase that have supported it through each version. Very few games and especially fighting games will ever have the longevity that Street Fighter IV has had and still has now. With Street Fighter V's beta fast approaching and that game already looks like it might be the successor that one would hope for after a title like Street Fighter IV, there is no better time than now to join into a game that has such a massive community and is both good for casuals and hardcore players. I will warn you that if you are fairly new, you might want to go into challenge mode and try some of the trials to learn a few basics before getting online as experienced players might hand you a bit of a whooping, but it is deffinitly a game that will forever be remembered.Street Fighter rarely disappoints and we have seen many great titles come out of the series. Ultra Street Fighter IV is a testement to how great the series can be and it also raised the standard for fighting games which is why many others since then have had trouble as they get seen as a bit of a side note, but I have played most of those as well. I highly recommend this title for old veterans of fighting games like myself to the newest of new interested in just trying one out. Either way you are likely to have fun.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												Ultra Street Fighter IV is the latest and (probably) last addition to the Street Fighter IV series. It features 5 new characters, new stages, new soundtrack and tons of balance changes to the roster. A word of advice to beginner fighters: Don't buy this game unless you have an arcade stick (fighting stick) or a good gamepad. The keyboard is not meant for fighting games, even if some people CAN make it work. Being good and enjoying a fighting game takes a lot of commitment. Hundreds of hours in minimum and thousands of hours realistically speaking.+Great gameplay. A good entry-level fighter for beginners too.+A huge roster of varied characters.+Good soundtrack with many iconic songs from the past.+Active community.+Smooth 60 FPS animation and beautiful visuals.-Mediocre netcode. Online multiplayer is still prone to lagging and connection time-outs. This is has been patched somewhat successfully and will be further patched in the future.-Could use a proper tutorial à la Skullgirls. There are character trials and a manual, but no real tutorial.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26
												A very solid, balanced, and timeless Street Fighter game. Where as newer fighters (Street Fighter V, MvC3, Street Fighter vs Tekken) feel like games of checkers, Street Fighter IV holds its own and plays like a game of chess. The game provides a variety of characters, each unique in their balanced set of strategic advantages/tactical allowances, and allows players to really discover that one character that matches their preferred style of play. The game does require investing some time to gain an understanding of the game's mechanics, level design, tactics commonly used by other players with each character, and their preferred character/character's core, but the time will pay off as you'll feel a greater sense of gratification and appreciation for the game and other players with each spar you engage in.Street Fighter IV is a game of SKILL. It requires the abilities to read one's opponents, quick reflexes, and the timely precision in executing inputs/deploying tactics. As mentioned many 2D fighters nowadays play like checkers in the sense that the bar for entry has been set too low for the sake of reaching a wider market and as a result increase profit generation. They feel as if the only worth they have is to those who want instant gratification in playing something that is easily accessible and off the bat sets an unbalanced win-loss ratio to their favor, leaning towards 'win'. This is apparent with MvC3's dedicated launch button and semi-unbreakable air combos that require a cheap guessing game of rock-paper-scissors to break out of. Street Fighter V and Street Fighter vs Tekken are also guilty of similar mundane juggling/gambling mechanics that one would expect to be integrated in the likes of a Mortal Kombat or a mobile game whose purposes and selling points are based on spetacle, cheap thrills, and the instant release of dopamine. The list of criticisms, for the above mentioned games, goes on and on (lets not get started on the gem system/shortcuts in SFxTekken), but if you want a game that is fun, entertaining, requires critical strategic/tactical thinking, and brings a sense of fulfillment with each match, Street Fighter IV is the cream of the crop.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												I'm not necessarily new to fighting games in general, but I am new to playing them 'seriously'.That being said, I've had the game for about a week now and I've already logged 36 hours in it- Ultra Street Fighter IV is fantastic and extremely easy to get into, though that may very well be due to the amount of friends I had that were already in to it before me. The only problems I've found is that the training portion doesn't hold your hand which is leaving me having to find out certain symbols used in the characters command lists on google when I feel that's unnecessary.By writing this it's clear that I do indeed have an internet connection, but why should I NEED to check google to find out how to play a game? I don't think it should be a necessity- but at least it helps newbie players out by often introducing them to pro players (like ChrisG or Justin Wong in case you happen to be infatuated with Elena like me) who can show you how to string the combos you'd like to get.The graphics are tight, the controls are tight (once you learn them), the Arcade Mode can be as rage inducing as it is mindless fun as it is fun always offering a new kind of challenge every time you play. The one thing I believe that's hurting USFIV, at least for this reviewer, is that at the time of writing this there is a HUGE problem with finding online matches. You can do co-op with friends and everything, but if you're looking to fight and make with friends with new peeps- Well, looks like you'll have to check out groups on Steam or find some fighter forums until the problem is fixed.However, if you're reading this after the glorious coming of the patch, do yourself a favor and drop this game in your cart.

												Really fun game, always something new to learn, and try to master. If you've read the other views, you probably noticed everyone is saying the multiplayer network is pretty bad, and I'd have to agree. However, I still end up playing online like everyday. During matches the game usually stutters once or twice, but other then that the game plays as smooth as butter. I would recommend the game despite it's shortcomings, but if Capcom were able to fix the network, I would recommend it even more to those looking for a fun fighting game. Besides, there aren't many fighters on PC, so there are not many to choose from.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												As much as I love Street Fighter, it seems to have fallen victim over time to being an example of the phrase “don’t fix that which is not broken.” Street Fighter II was the perfect fighting game in my opinion. You could just pick up a controller and pulverize people. Now Street Fighter has so many different game mechanics and each character is so much different from the others, which just makes it needlessly complicated. That’s not to say this is a bad game. Aside from the learning curve and pretty much the NECESSITY for a controller, this is a great game.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												Remember all the great fun you had playing Karate, Swordfight at Midnight, Fighting Road, and Super Black Belt Karate???  Of course you don't.  Why??  Because they all sucked a mile of chicken butt.  There's actually a long list of fighting games that have been put out to the masses over the years but only a choice few actually stand out amongst all the others as great and memorable fighting games.  Ultra Street Fighter IV along with the majority of the Street Fighter franchise is one of those few.  Pop quiz time...... Name all the current Ultra Street Fighter IV characters that also appeared in the original 1987 release of Street Fighter.  I'll give you the answer at the end.If you've never played a Street Fighter games now is a great time to try your hand at it.  Controls are smooth and easy to grasp with a little work.  Gameplay is realitively easy to grasp but difficult to master, which in my opinion is a mark of a great game.  Online play seems to be smooth and there's plenty to do solo too as no two fights, online or off, will ever be the same.  With all the different characters in USFIV there's bound to be at least one character you side with,  As a matter of fact, there's so many different characters that if there was a downside it's that it's hard to settle in on  just one fighter if you'r new.If you have played Street Fighter games before then what are you waiting for?  There's a fairly good chance at least one of your favorite characters from a previous version is just waiting for you to use them in a fight.  All your old memorized combos, supers, are still here and most likely use the same movements and button combos to execute.  And if you're looking for something new there's plenty of new and new/old characters too as well as some new moves and ultras.  This has certainly got to be one of the prettiest looking Street Fighters to date.  Colors pop, backgrounds look amazing and have loads of funny/interesting characters in them, and every character has several different DLC costumes you can buy if you so choose.  Other than the cosmetic character costumes though there's no game changing DLC within USFIV so yo don't need to worry about pay to win junk here.Overall the game looks and plays amazing and is great fun.  Since you can also play two player on the same screen/PC it also makes a great party game and looks amazing on a nice big screen TV or monitor.  If there was one major downside it would be that the game doesn't play well with a keyboard/mouse or a standard Xbox controller.  You can do it sure, but you'll most likely be at a disadvantage when playing against someone who has invested in and trained on a fightpad, fightstick, or one of the newer hitbox controllers.  Owning one of those types of controllers though opens up a world of other interesting gaming on Steam though as all fighting games and many other arcade style games found on Steam just feel better when you use one with it.So the answer to the question at the top:  Ryu, Ken, Gen, Adon, and Sagat.  There was also another character named Mike who greatly resembles the boxer Balrog so I guess he gets a half point...  Another character from the original Street Fighter named Eagle also appeared in Capcom vs SNK but not in USFIV.  There's your history lesson for today folks...

content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												This game is FANTASTIC! The combat is smooth like it was in Alpha 3; The fighters are better balanced and in greater numbers, and the skill ceiling is higher in this game than in any other street fighter (and in most other fighters). I prefer this  fighter over all other fighting games. I would definitely recommend this game to any fighting game finatic with alot of time to invest. The only things holding this game back from a perfect score are the occasional frame drops and the lag and lack of match making in online mode. Normally lag in online wouldn't hold a game back for me but the online lag in this game can be crippling, but if both players have a good connection online is just like fighting normally. All in all I give this game a 9/10, a must own for those who play fighters.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												I've played the game across platforms and over the various iterations since Street Fighter 4 came out. This iteration, on PC, is probably the worst I have played.The Good:-Since Street Fighter 4, this series has been highly accessible to a new audience. Large community.-Roster is very large now with a nice balance between characters-Not very demanding graphically-New Omega mode is very fun and interesting, breathing fresh air into old characters-The new delayed wakeup option and red focus seem to add new potential (and frustrations if your character relies on knockdown momentum)-Online training mode is a nice addition that can help new players learn from veterans regardless of physical locationThe Bad:-The netcode is easily the worst it has ever been. Games for Windows Live actually was a benefit to this series on PC. There were at least matches where you would not experience any latency. Not so anymore. Do not buy this for PC if you are a tournament player, want to play competitively, or want to improve your skills against other people in general. Period. You will never be able to tell when you have lost a match legitimately or when it was the delayed inputs that caused it. You will never have a match without high latency.-Half of the modes are untouched. I don't think I have used tournament mode or team battle more than a handful of times since they were introduced in Super Street Fighter 4. Online training suffers from the lag as well.Now you may say "That's not a lot of cons? Why are you not recommending this game?" The entire draw of the game is to play against other people via online. With the high latencies that appear like they won't be resolved any time soon, this game becomes highly frustrating on a good day. Even when I win the matches, I'm frustrated because I know the other player was feeling the same lag I was.It's not worth $40 on PC. It's not worth $15 on PC. It's probably not even worth $5. Unless you get this game gifted to you, do not buy it on steam. Buy it on a console and save yourself the trouble. I remain hopeful that Capcom will fix these issues someday, but it looks like they're already trying to milk me for some more money with Street Fighter 5.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
												As the series that many consider the core of the one-on-one fighting genre, Street Fighter has become a staple to many players.  With the latest version, it continues to prove why it has that reputation.  However, by showing why it was always a good series, it might be seen as a bad move.One thing that might be a bad thing about the game is the roster.  Having 44 characters is good because there is plenty of variety.  The part that is the minus is how many returning characters.  About 75 percent of the characters came from at least one other Street Fighter game.  This is the exact opposite of the previous game were 80 percent were original characters.  This does mean that fan favorites like Chun-Li and Dan are playable again.  However, with so many repeat characters, it makes it that the game does not much of a personality on its own but relying more on the nostalgia from past games.  A little more effort into creating more original characters than simply bringing back old ones would be more desirable.Even without the nostalgia, the combat is what makes it fun.  Even with having so many moves to use, the combat is simple enough for most players to pick up and play.  For those unfamiliar to the genre, the combat is simple enough for newcomers using just a couple of buttons to make a usable combo with three moves.  This makes it allows even those without prior knowledge can get into the game.  Once familiar with the mechanics, it becomes easy to pull off multi-move, double-digit combos.  With the system being this flexible, the one thing limiting the player is the desire to learn.However, with all the complexities of the game, the game does not do a good job in teaching how they work.  In Capcom’s previous fighting game Street Fighter X Tekken, there was a real training mode that teaches the player about all the various details about the combat system.  Unlike that game, this one does nothing to tell you about how things work.  There is a challenge mode where you can learn about combos, but that alone does not say what these mean.  To understand what the various symbols means, it is necessary to read the virtual manual.  Not having a physical manual might be normal nowadays, but with a system with many variances, this is a case where having something physical to read or a proper tutorial to study, many of these details are easily lost to the rookie player.Overall, this is still one of the great fighting series ever made.  Unfortunately, with the series getting more and more complicated, having a better teaching system is crucial.  Even without a proper manual or tutorial, the game is fun and deep enough to warrant any action fan to play.

												perhaps the best fighter on pc. don't be discouraged if you keep getting destroyed online, it takes time to get good at this game.if you are having problems with lag during online play it's most likely that you or the person you are playing doesn't have the right ports open. steam made it easy to get into pc gaming for the none technical types. though not always the case, many games require that certain ports are opened in order to function properly. sadly not many people have the technical know how to log into their router and configure it for pc gaming. i think capcom should program an alert message when you start the game informing the player to make sure the right ports are forwarded as well as a guide of some sort on how to configure your router.also don't forget that streaming services such as netflix are bandwidth hogs. so if you're sharing your internet with other people and they are using these services while you are gaming, unless you have some type of qos/traffic control implemented your online experience is going to suffer to some degree.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												If you're just getting into this game, don't do it alone - get some friends to tag along. The majority of the playerbase are veterans of the Street Fighter scene and are happy to eat up new players. It's difficult to input special moves correctly with a controller and impossible to play with keyboard/mouseYou'll want to invest in a joystick...it'll still take a long time to get the inputs consistent, thoughIt feels almost like a guessing game at times, but you can tip the scales in your favour if you can recognize patterns in the other player's gameplayThe game engine demands dedication.It's sometimes difficult to simply land a special move on its own, but you aren't going to win much if you don't learn to string moves together (forming a combo) at a timing that's sometimes as tight as 1/60th of a second.Enter at your own risk.EDITAfter playing for awhile, I'd like to point out that combos with a margin of error of only 1/60th of a second are far and few between You can go far without that sort of thing, but know these combos do exist

												Some people would recommend this to be your 1st Fighting game to play. Reasons being it requires a LOT of different techniques to be able to play against a decent (over 1000PP) players. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 16, 2015
												Let me tell you something you may already know. This game ain't all shoryuken and rainbows.When you first start, it’s a very mean and nasty place and I don’t care how good of a gamer you think you are -- it will beat you to your knees and keep you there if you let it. You will lose your first game.. you will probably lose your 2nd game.. you may even lose 30 in a row (like me...) But..remember.. it ain't about how hard ya hit. It's about how hard you can GET hit and keep moving forward. How much you can TAKE and keep moving forward. THAT'S HOW WINNING IS DONE (i just won 2 in a row woot 2W-30L). But ya gotta be willing to take the hits, and not pointing fingers about to uninstall saying you ain't where you want to be because of cheesers, hackers, or anybody! Noobs do that and that ain't you! You're better than that! ADRIANtl;drget this game if u got da will of a championp.s.  u may want to invest in a fightstick or hitbox if you are on a controller.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												If you're not familiar to street fighter or any fighting games then you will be in for a crash course lesson with SSF4AE. Street fighter has had a long and successful history at being one of the best fighting games around which goes to say that this game is in no way a dissappointment. There are a huge number of characters to choose from each providing new and different styles for fighting. The original characters such as Ken and Ryu are as formidable as ever while newer characters such as C.Viper and Juri really put a spin on the fighting stlyes familiar to SF4.If you find yourself being KO'ed too often then you can dial down the difficulty in arcade and versus mode when playing against the computer but against other players, I'm afraid only god can save you then. This goes to say that online mode especially now that the game has been out for some time is filled with experienced players so you'll need to put some hours in the training room.All in all this is a great fighting game for beginners and experienced fighting nuts, with this game being continually updated with more characters especially with Ultra street fighter 4 already being released on console and coming soon on PC, you can be sure to find a great balanced fighting game if you buy this and future editions.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												As of launch day for Ultra:Top notch fighting game, Ultra's balance adjustments and additional systems (such as red focus and delayed wake up) to SF4 puts every character on a more even playing field, especially those who had no answer to vortexes.The only gripe with the game is the online play. Since Super Street Fighter 4 Arcade Edition's transition from Games for Windows Live (GFWL) to Steam servers the online play has seen a noticeable drop in quality (i.e. laggier). And the transition from SSF4AE ver 2014 to to Ultra has seen another lagtastic dip, at least for me. Matches are playable, and the "Waiting for opponent" doesn't pop up like it did in SSF4AE2014, but on occasion the match will slow down as both of us in the match try to distance ourselves from each other until the game goes back to normal speed.It will likely get fixed over time, as the server structures between the two are likely very different. The netcode probably has been or had to be re-written to transition from one to the other, but may still need to be adjusted.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2012
												A very decent follow-up after Super Street Fighter 2.  Capcom did release some sequels but while the Alpha franchise represented a prequel and part 3 did have a new storyline, Street Figther 4 is the direct follow-up after part 2.Super Street Figther IV: Arcade Edition has the same roster as Street Figther IV, but with an extra 14 characters. The game is very entertaining - visually superb and its gameplay is very addictive. I can only recommend it, especially since there are barely any 2D fighters available on PC nowadays.UPDATE: Ultra Street Figther 4 is a decent DLC making 5 more characters available as part of the already huge roster. I have only played a couple of hours with the DLC content but already met all the new characters as enemies - it seems they offer quite varied moves and playing them will be interesting and, hopefully, challenging.What I noticed is that it is possible now to use both Ultra Moves - the 3rd ultra choice is actually making both available (on the character screen). So, why pick only one of them in the future? Because making both available means they do less damage. Still, the variation can be helpful if fighting a particular enemy. Also, I hated those ultras where it was a requirement to be hit by the enemy or simply let them close. Now, it's best to have both at the ready.Another thing is that as Windows Live is not available anymore (or simply just not supported - I have not really followed related news), achievements are now logged via Steam and of course updating the game will also be easier. New characters also means new stages and new soundtracks for these. My favourite is the Jurassic Park one with the two dinosaurs constantly roaring in the background.Multiplayer seems to be finetuned and I noticed a Youtube upload option for the matches we have played. I hope this time it will be easier to find opponents - whether it is a netcode issue or the fact that this is not played by many on PC is still unknown for me.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
												My favorite fighting game of all time. I remember playing street fighter II at the arcade in my childhood. Still a big fan today, can't ask for a better game. Thank you Capcom for developing this. The graphics are stunning, characters are unique, and complex fighting mechanics that are easy to learn, but difficult to master. It's hard to be good in this game without spending hours in training mode. The mechanics in this game will not let you mash the buttons to perform a move, but it requires strict timing in order for the moves or combo to come out. Once you master the techniques and timing, it will pay off when you play competitively. The thing that impress me the most is the cool moves that each individual character has. The level of details in every fighters' muscles and little extra effects when a punch lands on an opposite always leaves me in awe. The sound of every punch is crispy clear. Just the cracking sound of knuckles landing on my oppoent's face always gets me high. Honestly, you really have to get this game and see for yourself. This is a number one choice for any fight games fanboy out there.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												Ingredients:1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour3 tablespoons sugar1 tablespoon baking powder1/4 teaspoon salt1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg2 large eggs, at room temperature1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as neededNow to make it1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg.2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla.3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat.4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed.6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												Outdated design? CheckClunky gameplay? CheckSlow gameplay? CheckBoring gameplay? CheckFun to mess around with friends in? CheckAs far as fighting games go, there's no game that frustrates me more than SF4. The core game design is clunky, limited, and slow. It makes me feel trapped because all that matters is single attacks into special moves with some grabs thrown in here and there (and, of course, projectile spam but every fighting game has that). There's no comboing worth anything, minimal pressure game, and Capcom still hasn't realized just how terrible a design idea charged attacks is. As a whole, the game is unejoyable because the core game design is more akin to a boxing match than a fighting game: single hits now and then to slowly chip away at the opponent until they fall over.You know a fighting game has a problem when the fastest characters are played best at midrange, sitting and waiting to get a hit in then back away and repeat. That, and such a drastic difference in power between the top and the bottom.I give SF4 a 4/10. It would be a 3, but the game is coded well with minimal to NO bugs which is a huge plus. I do not recommend Ultra Street Fighter 4 (or any other version of SF4) to anyone who wants to play a fun fighting game.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												Probably the best 2D fighting game out there and with a huge following to boot. But I wouldn't recommend the game to anyone as it is right now. The reason being that the steam integration has royally failed even though they have had so much time on their hands to make it work. -Mic is ON by default and there is no in-game option to switch it off much less change anything related to voice communication.-Announcer is really loud and repeats almost any phrase twice and sometimes echoes.-Achievement don't transfer properly, for example if you have won 500 games you still have to win one more to trigger it, some achievements like simply setting an icon and title you have to do over to trigger.-Game says there is an option to switch version which there clearly isn't (it looks like a port from the regular SSF4)-Net code is a hit/miss, worse than with GFWL, I truly don't get why people hated on it so much, I merely had the discomfort of having to type in my info once every 20 days or so due to inactivity otherwise it logged me in automatically.-NO-ONE is online, game can't find anyone. Match request works to an extent which is weird, makes me think it's just me although i have never had any problems with any game I play online.However...If you are willing and have faith you are better off getting the game now while it's on sale and save yourself the smack on the head later. Issues are not unheard off but keep in mind it can take a long time before they fix this depend on how priority it is given.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												People like you and me "suck at it", because when we play online, we play against people who are frame counters. These people will research every single move there is, until eventually they are able to counter and punish every single action you make.For example, they know how long it takes for a Hadoken to be performed, so they look at fighters who are programmed with a timing that will be fast enough to punish that move. To me this is equivalent of playing poker with a bunch of card counters, it doesn't matter to them if you are playing for fun, they are playing statistics. I really wish that the programmers for these types of games would but 3 or four different ways/timings that are randomly performed for each move. For example, when you press "jab", sometimes it takes 0.2 seconds to connect, sometimes it will take 0.5 seconds to connect. That way it will be like a real fight, and everyone would be in the same playing field.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
												One of the most ridiculously complicated fighting games ever made, with a ton of flaws to stop people getting in to it without thousands of hours of practice. Many of the problems with it have in fact been fixed in SFV, but sadly SFV is extremely lacking in terms of content as of now, so many people are stuck here.So, why is it so bad, you ask?One-Frame LinksStreet Fighter fanboys will defend this nonsense until the end of the earth, and it's one of the most ridiculously stupid things I have ever seen.The general idea behind one-frame links is that when you do an attack and want to follow it up with another, only the joystick's input is buffered. You cannot buffer the button presses, and instead, they must be pressed in a lot of cases, completely frame perfect on the second that attack frame ends.  Not only is this an incredibly needless execution barrier that keeps newer players out, it's also made worse by the fact the online has a hideous delay, making these frame-perfect links almost impossible.These one-frame links are so bad, an in-game exploit known as 'Priority Linking', or 'Plinking', is commonly used in competitive play to increase the leniency of these links. You can tell you've got a needlessly complex game if even the professional players have to exploit the system to pull off their combos. SFV has in fact, fixed these frame links, and according to the developer, the minimum amount of frames needed to do a link has gone down to three.The game's tutorials are terrible, especially regarding movesThis is perhaps the worst thing, in my opinion. You'll quite often be in a match and you'll be struck down over and over, not knowing how to counter a certain move. Do you block high, block low? How are you to know? The ingame move-list for each character doesn't tell you a damn thing about anything. Is this move projectile-invincible, does it break armor?The only way to find out ANY of this is to look the information up on community wiki's, and considering how many characters there are and how many moves you need to learn the properties of, it's almost shameful that the game can't just tell you this.The community is easily one of the worst in the FGCConsider this a deviation with no real inpact on the game, it's more of a personal gripe. When the majority of your game is done online, it's not the best of things to have people taunting you and sending you invites to 'LOL YOU'RE BAD XDDDD' steam groups after every other match. Consider this because of the normalisation of Street Fighter as a game, tons of people play it, which brings in the majority of bad eggs that you see. But this kind of behavior is often seen at professional tournaments, too, which doesn't help to bring down the image of the FGC as a whole.If you're considering getting into fighting games, I'd very much recommend you pick up Skullgirls to start you off. SF4 is not a beginner-friendly game, and has an enormous execution barrier that will stop you from getting the full enjoyment of this game until you're thousands of hours into the game. There are much better fighting games that you could be playing. I only hope SFV gets more fleshed out as time goes on.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												Outdated design? CheckClunky gameplay? CheckSlow gameplay? CheckBoring gameplay? CheckFun to mess around with friends in? CheckAs far as fighting games go, there's no game that frustrates me more than SF4. The core game design is clunky, limited, and slow. It makes me feel trapped because all that matters is single attacks into special moves with some grabs thrown in here and there (and, of course, projectile spam but every fighting game has that). There's no comboing worth anything, minimal pressure game, and Capcom still hasn't realized just how terrible a design idea charged attacks is. As a whole, the game is unejoyable because the core game design is more akin to a boxing match than a fighting game: single hits now and then to slowly chip away at the opponent until they fall over.You know a fighting game has a problem when the fastest characters are played best at midrange, sitting and waiting to get a hit in then back away and repeat. That, and such a drastic difference in power between the top and the bottom.I give SF4 a 4/10. It would be a 3, but the game is coded well with minimal to NO bugs which is a huge plus. I do not recommend Ultra Street Fighter 4 (or any other version of SF4) to anyone who wants to play a fun fighting game.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												I cannot condemn this game enough.  Just don't.  If you find yourself thinking - maybe it's not that bad; don't.  It's awful.See the problem is Windows Live.  Yeah.  I didn't read the notes before buying it.The first issue I ran into was just trying to find my account details.  I avoid Windows Live like the plague because I have yet to have a good experience using it.  This means I don't use it very often and - unsurprisingly - had forgotten my password.  This is exacebated by Microsofts ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ password requirements which include never being able to re-use a password already used in live.  Fortunately I'd written it down and after a bit of digging found it.Alright I'm in.  Gotta accept the terms and conditions before I can install though.  It's a pity there seems to be no way to access them before money is paid but that's pretty much par for the couse these days.  But wait there's more I can't read the terms and conidtions at all - they're missing.  Not a problem - I'll blindly accept them like everyone else.But wait there's more.  I need a CD key.  In this day and age I really still need CD keys?  Oh well it's Capcom and Microsoft; two companies whose grasp of realitiy is poor at best tending tripping balls in general.  Good thing I can copy that CD key into the clipboard otherwise I might have to type it out.  Gotcha!  Windows Live doesn't respect 'paste' (or anything else) so I'm going to be typing it in after all.  I guess it's just a part of the challenge.Glad that's over.  I'll be waiting whilst my profile is downloaded - not that I realised I already had one so that's a bit of a bonus!  Except it turns out that the lengthly profile download is actually the key authentication.  Who'd a thought it.  And I got the key wrong.  Okay, this is a bit of a problem now - I'm only running an a full HD TV and it's really, really hard to tell the difference between 6 and 8.  And that key liked it's sixes and eights.After some trial and error I managed to guess the right combination of 6s and 8s - turns out it wasn't 666 although I'm still not convinced that Live is not in league with the devil.  But that wasn't all somewhere in the trialling and the erroring Windows Live crashed and lost all my account details I'd asked it to kindly save upfront.  Off to find them again.At last I'm in.  I verified I really did buy the game I bought.  I was getting worried I might not be me.Except it was never going to be that easy was it?  Windows Live (which had just updated itself) detected there was an update and infomred me I wouldn't be able to play until I've installed it.  Fine it's getting a bit needy but I let it update again.  Which incidently loses my account information again too.  I can almost remeber the random string of symbols and caps and numbers that is my password now so we can move on.At this point Live get's itself into a 'I have to restart but I can't restart know\ which is easilly solved by killing the process.  Silly LIve it could have just done that itself.And there are new terms and conditions I have to accept before I'll be allowed to play again.  This time there wasn't even an option to view them.  I can accept that Microsoft would never possibly try and sneak a devious clause into it's terms and condiitions so without ado I continue.  And I won.  I am winner.Wait, was I reviiewing Street Fighter or Games for Windows Live?

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												This game is one of the definitive, modern fighting games.  It is balanced, nuanced, and visually dynamic.  It is also completely impenetrable to someone who has little or no experience with fighting games or the Street Fighter series.  Being a newcomer to the series, I found this game to make zero effort to explain or even give the basic fundamentals of how to play.  Even the challenges and training modes are woefully inadequate to teach the game.  If you love fighting games or are familiar with the series, Street Fighter IV is a great game.  If you aren't, you shouldn't bother trying to play unless you want to dedicate a serious amount of time playing, watching videos, and reading about it.  This isn't a bad game.  It just is really hard to recommend to people who aren't already fans or willing to put an incredible number of hours into the game.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												I waited a lot before writing this review because this awesome game is cursed by a really bad netcode implementation, I thought the issues could be fixed but since after 2 months the situation is almost the same I think things are going to remain like that forever. Anyway, let's start with everything else, we will get there eventually.The game is, as was SSFIV AE, one of the best fighting games ever made. The roster is huge and the gameplay of each character is unique (shotos share similarities ofc). Usually with a huge roster tier list gets crazy but in Ultra Street Fighter IV there are almost no impossible match-ups.Graphics are really nice and on PC you can customize even more game's graphic settings, music is really good (character bgm are better than stage bgm IMHO, but that's just for me) and SFX/announcer are part of what makes the game street fighter.Now let's talk about the netcode implementation. When you buy a fighting game you're not supposed to play alone by design.In 2000 you wouldn't expect the game to have any online mode implementation and you'd have struggled to search players at your level (it involved moving around your country a lot) to learn the game and eventually enjoy yourself.In 2014 you expect your game to be fully playable online since 30~40 ms ping values are totally bearable (it's more or less 2 game frames that should even be mitigated by the netcode). Sadly this is not the case.The netcode is bad and so the "mitigation" is completely missing (at least it feels like that) meaning that if you play with low ping values (let's say <40ms) outside ranked, the game plays fine, otherwise you will experience totally unplayable games.To recap, gameplay 10 (wouldn't make major changes), graphic 9 (it's old but on PC you can enhance it), music/SFX 9 (totally enjoyable), netcode 2 (well, read above)

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
												DO NOT PICK UP THIS GAME IF YOU HAVE NEVER EXTENSIVELY PLAYED STREET FIGHTER BEFOREHANDPeople told me this would be a great place to start playing Street Fighter since I couldnt afford V. That was not true. This game's tutorial does not teach you anything adequately for online play, and as of now, all of the community has migrated. The mechanics are choppy and clunky for everyone but the most experienced of players, and after playing for almost 5 hours straight, I am unable to do a TUTORIAL PROMPTED 2-HIT COMBO due to the extremely specific and overly strict timing of these "combo" systems. I wouldn't even call them "combos". If you dont have a major in rocket science and advanced mathematics, or if you dont have unlimited free time and dedication to play this game for 1000+ hours just to get "AVERAGE", DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												For fighting game fanatics only. This game is way too hard for a casual player, even on the lowest difficulties the AI can counter-play a less skilled player with impunity. Special moves require high manual dexeterity to be performed and Ultra combos... well let's say you will never see any casual player perform these moves. Street Fighter DS allowed you at least to put certain button combinations (like the Ultra Combo) onto the touch screen for one-tap controls.The several (seemingly deliberate) entry barriers for new players and the unforgiving difficulty are nothing for a casual player who wants a quick game and the Arcade-Style controls are a relict from the past.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												I hope i help anyone with their decison on this game and be happy forward on with their games. please read this review.i put good work into it and it wont take much of your time please and thank you for your cooperation.this game is good.however this game is not for everbody.if your very patient,youll enjoy this game.if not you'll hate this game.the gameplay is pretty good and there are 44 characters.playing the game is like mixing colors in knowing what works & what doesnt and knowing how to use you character against others(training room is recommended for practice).the graphics looks good and there is matchmaking online. only thing i dont like focus.it feels it counters fundamentals and you can just easily focus.idk.its just me.ultras i feel people can just use it and the helath bars will be even again the next round is not affected at all by this except who wins.the super metter i feel does better because it carries over.ultra is spam it on an opening and youll get full damage without really earning it.it feels cheap now the negatives(oh boy). this game is insanely precise in execution on almost everything and online is functional and can be good at times,but it handicaps you because the links for combos have to be pressed at such a precise moment, even on beginner things & fluidity can make you drop things and be inconsistent because it feels weird compared to offline(get friends with good conenctions,recommended)there is no story unless you care about the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ arcade mode that is no where as good as mk9.no tutorial on how to play the game and many things and secrets the game wont tell you like option selects,plinking,etc.trials dont show you anything,just do moves.who are these characters,and barely any content to do in the game.its mostly barebones meaning all you have is endless, ranked, & training room.the other modes no one is using them.you have a replay channel,but since online is inconsistent sometimes,it can be hardly a prize.the ♥♥♥♥ed up part is that in omega mode,its allot easier to do all these combos because you have a bigger window and more accuracy and consistency to press the button to continue the combos(sfv combos feel like omega).its not insanely precise and you dont have to wait for the animation to finish. trust me, these things that should be easy when you learn them are hard as ♥♥♥♥.ive been using cammy for a long time and i refuse to believe that the game tells me i cant do crouching jab, jab, strong into spiral arrow because of online.thats unnacepptable.another thing is that this game was supposed to be optimized just like the consoles,what i mean is that when you practice on pc and then go play on consoles(except ps3 because i think pc is similiar to it when i played on that console) where the tournaments are on, everything is delayed and feels weird when you do your things, but spend enough time, youll get use to it. i thought it was impossbile, but i actually ended up doing pretty well in a tourney from home with pc to tourney with xbox 360. i spoke with combofiend and he said it was already established or to stay that way by capcom themselves. thats why they didnt change usf4 to make it easier like omega mode or make the pc version exactly like the consoles. that is ♥♥♥♥ed up! another thing i should tell you is that when you go online to fight someone, there is no way for you to know if youll have a good connection or a bad one because the bar rating which is black to green bars and in between, fluctuates. in green bars you might have a bad or a good connection, red,orange,black,etc. the only way to know the connection is to play that person once and sometimes its hard to really know just by one match because the game itself even offline is so precise already.this is why most tourney players dont consider online no where as steady as offline because its too easy to drop things and it constantly changes from the real thing which is offline where tournaments are played.you have to rely stuff like double tapping and p linking in order to not drop your moves instead of just simply doing the moves without doing such unneccessary execution! you feel your fighting the game itself rather than your opponent(like combofiend said lol!) there is no reason for you to make a game so hard when people will look for somthing hard to do in the game anyway! If i know how to do something i know how to do it!knowledge should always beat execution.ALWAYS BEATS EXECUTION!PERIOD.Also if your looking for good tourney players like me and others who know what they are doing with option selects,secrets,expliots, tech, and everything,good luck trying to find them on pc(consoles less hard though) because its hard to find them and youll find mostly people who do random stuff because they dont know any better and you even lose to them because of bad connection.this sucks!also the point system and matchmaking is bs.you have people who are over 10000 BP and all they did was do random moves you cant react to online.the ranking and point system is inconsistent it makes dummies look like pros.if this doesnt tell you how inconsistent online is,idk what does. i sometimes get discconected in matches,from steam in training,and even for winning one round in 2 out of 3.even sometimes the game freezes in lag spikes while playing & also keeps putting me with people that have lower points than me when i put more skilled in my settings which is suppose to put ones with higher points than me.WTF!?I even wanted to be #1 cammy and train hard for it, but why should i go through these problems anyway if online couldve been better fixed? it like walking for hours instead of waiting for a car that shouldve picked you up,but didnt when they were supposed to. its disapointing cause i really wanted to do it.anyway if you want this game get it at the lowest sale if your not sure,but i wouldnt recommend it if you have console.this game might die most likely & sfv is around the corner(if you want,get sfv instead)even if you have the game on console and want it on pc,just play it on console already unless you really want it. not much is differentthis is a fun game when you know what your doing,i just personally feel this game couldve been better with the things ive mentioned fixed, more things, easier inputs etc. i cant recommend this game to new people or even ones experienced from other games.there is just so much they have to do to get started like watch youtube videos on option selects,characters,etc.that its really a commitment your doing in order to be good at it.VERDICT: pc: 5/10 average console: 6/10 above average(pc has more problems online)i hope sfv is better than usf4 and improves on everything from the previous game and becomes great.get sfv if you dont want usf4,but if your going to get usf4,get it at least for the challenge.my experience was a struggle,but i wanted to try other games because i felt its good to have more knowledge from them and i was right.the decision to purchase the game is yours.the reason i dont give a thumbs up is because i dont reccomend this game at full price especially with dlc costumes because we all know capcom is so good at doing those things and whats mentioned,so its pretty fair i do that.Also i understand that things take time to get better at what your doing, but i think allot of people would agree with me that some things in the game didnt have to be what they are already.ive met people that have gotten frustrated over this game and left.those players i wouldnt balme them and they arent wrong either because capcom designed it that way.mkx and skullgirls are hard when you want to be really good at them,but they have allot better welcoming and comfort for those not that experienced.usf4 has nothing to offer to welcome outsiders.its horrible at tha area,but i guess that why sfvs looks like its going the way its going huh.(sigh) man i miss the old capcom.
